snippet.title: No Hesitation In Condemning Violence: Trinamool's Dinesh Trivedi To NDTV
snippet.description:
Senior Trinamool Congress leader Dinesh Trivedi has condemned violence of any kind while speaking to NDTV on the attack on BJP chief JP Nadda's convoy in West Bengal. He said violence has no place in the civil society and that while elections will come and go, one must remember that political parties are adversaries and not enemies.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | India's Farm Sector Reforms: Why Should Consensus Be The Casualty?
snippet.description:
The farmers' agitation has been going on for months now. But the last one week has seen a sudden flare up along Delhi's borders. Ultimately, the government listened. Meetings have taken place. Why a situation like this had to arise in the first place? Some experts notice a trend in the Central government's style of functioning - taking a decision at any cost instantly and then managing the consequences. Article 370, CAA, and now the farm laws -- all efforts on building the consensus come after a decision has been taken. On The Big Fight, we ask a very elementary question: Why is consensus the casualty?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Voice Of Farmers Not Going To Be Silenced: Congress MP Deepender Hooda
snippet.description:
Watch full epsiode of The Big Fight: https://youtu.be/DfRziK2cOpE

On a day farmers entered the national capital, but not before facing water cannons, tear gas and barricades, Congress MP from Haryana Deepender Hooda said, "Farmers' voice is not going to be silenced." "Chief Minister of Haryana has gone on record to say that he will quit politics if farmers don't get MSP (minimum support price). Convert what you are saying into some form of law because in the three laws you have brought in, you have not mentioned MSP once."

snippet.title: Barbed Wires, Trenches, Was It Line of Control or Haryana: P Sainath
snippet.description:
Watch full epsiode of The Big Fight: https://youtu.be/DfRziK2cOpE

It was a victory for protesting farmers. The central government finally blinked and allowed them to enter Delhi. But this wasn't before days of clashes and confrontations between the farmers and the police. Even today, farmers faced barricades, water cannons and tear gas shells as they tried to enter the national capital. Speaking to NDTV, founder-editor of PARI P Sainath asked, "Barricades, barbed wires, Border Security Force, 10-foot trenches, water cannons... was that the Line of Control or was it Haryana?" On the question of Minimum Support Price, he said, "If you (PM Narendra Modi) are so firm on the MSP, if you are so clear that no one and nothing can take it away, you have rammed through three complex heavy bills, put in one more, two paragraphs guaranteeing that MSP."

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Will Government Roll Back Farm Laws?
snippet.description:
After two days of face-offs, the authorities allowed protesting farmers, some of whom threw stones and broke barricade, to enter Delhi under police escort to stage a demonstration against agricultural reforms they fear will leave them at the mercy of big corporations. The police had deployed hundreds of personnel at different entry points to the national capital, parking trucks full of sand and laying barbed wire to block the farmers' path. The farmers have been upset with the laws passed earlier this year which mean they are now free to sell their produce to anyone at any price, instead of to state-controlled markets at assured rates. They say the new laws deregulating the vast agriculture sector will leave small growers vulnerable to corporate agri-businesses and could lead to a withdrawal of price supports for staples like wheat and rice. On The Big Fight, we ask: will the government roll back the farm laws?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Bihar Election Has Important Lessons For West Bengal?
snippet.description:
Bihar Assembly Election Results: The battle for Bihar may have been over but the war seems to continue. While the NDA stakes claim to form government on the basis of a wafer-thin majority, RJD's Tejashwi Yadav has raised allegations against "counting problem". Also, the BJP is eyeing a victory in West Bengal and elections are scheduled next year. Does Bihar have a lesson for everyone?

snippet.title: India Shouldn't Be Seen as Taking Sides: Salman Khurshid on France and Islamic Backlash
snippet.description:
Amid a global debate on Islamophobia vs Islamofascism, India, in an unprecedented position, has openly backed French President Emmanuel Macron, calling the personal attacks on him deplorable. Speaking to NDTV, former foreign minister and senior Congress leader, Salman Khurshid, said, "We have always been seen as non-aligned in more ways than one and I do hope that we will continue to be non-aligned, although very clearly in favour of peace, in favour of humanity .... but beyond that, to fish in troubled waters might not be advisable."

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Backlash Against France: Islamophobia vs 'Islamofascism'
snippet.description:
There is a global debate raging around two words - Islamophobia and Islamofascism. India has taken an unprecedented position in favour of France. New Delhi has openly backed French President Emmanuel Macron calling the personal attacks on him deplorable. Meanwhile, many people say that there is a duplicity in the argument of Islamic countries. They are united against France but silent on China's Muslim persecution. Why? On the Big Fight, we look at Islamic backlash against France and the debate over it. And we decode India's unprecedented stand.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Bihar: A PM Modi Vs Tejashwi Yadav Elections?
snippet.description:
Election fever is now at its peak in Bihar. The big guns are out. PM Narendra Modi will have 12 rallies. Tejashwi Yadav is having 12 rallies every day. Meanwhile there is a side script in the NDA with Chirag Paswan. He claims to be with BJP, though BJP claims to be with Nitish Kumar. Rahul Gandhi has also hit the campaign trail, criticising PM Modi. But this time around, one notices a peculiar trend. Gone are the days when Nitish Kumar led the NDA in Bihar. Is this a case where he has had to pillion ride on PM Modi's popularity, that too after 15 years of leading a government? In his speeches, he mentions more about the central government schemes than his own. On The Big Fight, we ask: Has the Bihar election now become about mainly two personalities - Tejashwi Yadav and Narendra Modi?

snippet.title: Tanishq Ad Withdrawal: Support Pours After Vicious Trolling
snippet.description:
The problem we face most is what to accept as reality and what not to. So the easiest way to decode this is to define it as good reality and bad reality. First the good reality: inter-faith marriages and inter-faith harmony exists in this country. It is a fact. But then there is the bad reality as well. Communal clashes and religious conflict too is a reality in this country. But what do we want to celebrate is going to define our character. Will we celebrate our unity or our differences? The Tanishq advertisement withdrawal has kick-started this very basic and fundamental debate. Have we all started celebrating the bad reality where we celebrate and accept bigotry and communal differences?

snippet.title: Exams Amid Pandemic: Is There Need For An Out-Of-The-Box Solution?
snippet.description:
The Supreme Court has ruled that final-year degree exams must be held across the country and no students can be promoted without holding exams. The top court had earlier given the go-ahead for NEET and JEE entrance examinations. However, amid rising Covid cases and parts of the country affected by floods, can the state and central governments rise above political bickering and think of a solution that helps the students? Dr Ajoy Kumar and Vaman Acharya face-off on The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Is It Hypocritical For Rajasthan Govt To Protest Against NEET, JEE Exams?
snippet.description:
The Rajasthan government has moved the Supreme Court to review its order to go ahead for the NEET and JEE exams. However, the Rajasthan Public Service Commission exams were held in the state, with the students physically appearing for exams. In the light of these facts, is it hypocritical for the state government to participate in the protest against the exams? Or is the Rajasthan government justified in its actions? Geeta Bhatt and Gourav Vallabh face off on The Big Fight

snippet.title: Design Exams That Can Be Taken At Home: Shashi Tharoor
snippet.description:
Congress MP Shashi Tharoor tells NDTV that the government must look at rescheduling the NEET, JEE exams to after Diwali and urged the government to design exams that can be taken at home in case the pandemic situation worsens. "Online centres can be designated to those who do not have access to internet. But the majority of the students will take the exams at home, without creating the problem of crowding. These two options must be explored very seriously," he said.

snippet.title: No Issues Inside Centre, But Outside A Complete Nightmare: NEETprep.com CEO To NDTV
snippet.description:
The Supreme Court on Monday dismissed a plea seeking postponement of JEE (Main) and NEET-Undergraduate examinations, which are scheduled to be conducted in September, amid a spurt in number of COVID-19 cases, saying precious years of the students "cannot be wasted". Despite massive online protest against holding of medical and engineering entrance exams during COVID, the government says there is no question of postponing and that life must go on. Kapil Gupta the CEO of NEETprep.com told NDTV, "The document uploaded by the National Testing Agency (NTA) on their website talks about things that will happen inside the exam centre. But inside the centre is not an issue. It is the outside which is a complete nightmare."

snippet.title: Exams During COVID Akin To Suicide, Says Mehak Mittal, A JEE Aspirant
snippet.description:
In May, the NEET & JEE examinations were postponed when the country was logging fewer cases daily. But now the government has decided to go ahead with the examinations when the daily case count is exploding and is the highest globally. Concerned students and parents moved court and the Supreme Court said that NEET and JEE exams would be held as per schedule. The matter is between the students and their government. Should the government be making the mistake of treating this as a flash-in-the-pan protests? Should students bow down to a determined government? Or should the government show compassion to at least attempt to work on solutions? Mehak Mittal, a JEE aspirant, tells NDTV, "I just want to ask a simple question to the government. Is one academic year more important or the lives of 25 lakh JEE & NEET aspirants? Who will take the responsibility if a student becomes COVID positive after the examination? Exams during covid is just like suicide."

snippet.title: Conducting Exams Now Won't Be Accurate Measure Of Talent: Shashi Tharoor
snippet.description:
There's a massive protest online against the Centre's decision to conduct the medical (NEET) and engineering (JEE) exams in September amid the coronavirus pandemic. The hashtag #ProtestAgainstExamsInCOVID has been trending on social media with nearly three million tweets. Speaking to NDTV on the issue, Congress MP Shashi Tharoor said, "Many students are away from their exam centres as they have gone back to their families during the lockdown. Many have not been able to study the normal way." The time is far from ideal to conduct examinations and as a result it will not be an accurate measure of talent and academic capability, he said.

snippet.title: Students' Lives As Important As Their Future: Political Analyst Geeta Bhatt Tells NDTV
snippet.description:
The Joint Entrance Exam (JEE), for admission to engineering courses, and National Eligibility cum Entrance Test (NEET), for admission to medical courses, will go ahead as scheduled and admit cards for the JEE (Main) exam have already been issued by the National Testing Agency (NTA). This happened amid a massive online protest against conducting exams during the COVID-19 pandemic. It was the top trend on social media with nearly three million tweets. Supporting the government's move, Geeta Bhatt, a political analyst, tells NDTV, "Students' lives are important but so is their future."

snippet.title: COVID-19: India Reports Over 50,000 Cases Second Times In A Row
snippet.description:
India on Friday reported a new record surge in coronavirus cases with more than 55,000 fresh infections. The Union Health Ministry said that over 6.42 lakh samples were tested on Thursday which is the highest single-day figure so far. This is the second consecutive day that more than 50,000 new cases have been reported in 24 hours.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Over 50,000 Coronavirus Cases A Day: Are We Doing Enough?
snippet.description:
The coronavirus is still out there, stronger than ever and invisible. It affects you more directly than you think. It is killing more than you think. We are now growing at a pace faster than any other country and  the recovery rate remains a cause of worry. Now, 55,000 cases are being added each day and life is not normal. On The Big Fight, we bring the focus back to where it should be Covid-19.

snippet.title: MLAs Answerable To Electorate: Sachin Pilot's Lawyer Mukul Rohatgi
snippet.description:
Rajasthan Political Crisis: Sachin Pilot's Counsel, Mukul Rohatgi, tells NDTV that an MLA is answerable to his electorate. If the electorate wants him to do something even if it is against the views of the Chief Minister, then Sachin Pilot will have to do it but that cannot lead to disqualification, he said.

snippet.title: Rajasthan: Debate Around Constitutional Crisis
snippet.description:
Rajasthan Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot today demanded an assembly session 'as soon as possible' and protested for more than four hours at Governor Kalraj Mishra's house, accusing him of sitting on the request because he was 'under pressure' to stall a test of strength. The Chief Minister submitted a list of 102 MLAs to the Governor, who asked him to send a fresh request for a session.

snippet.title: Politics Vs People: Real Equation Missing In Rajasthan?
snippet.description:
Rajasthan Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot has submitted a list of 102 MLAs to Governor Kalraj Mishra. This as the governor wrote to the Chief Minister saying - neither justification nor any agenda has been proposed to call the session on such a short notice. He also spoke of explanation being sought on how to convene the session amid coronavirus pandemic.

snippet.title: Rajasthan Crisis: Ambition Vs Ideology
snippet.description:
Sachin Pilot repeatedly asked to be made Chief Minister of Rajasthan within one year and refused to meet with Congress chief Sonia Gandhi and son Rahul Gandhi unless they were ready to accept his demand, sources close to party leader Priyanka Gandhi Vadra said on Friday. Mr Gehlot, who has repeatedly accused Mr Pilot of conspiring with the BJP to bring down his government, may be in for huge trouble if a few more MLAs join the 20-strong rebel camp.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Vikas Dubey: The Truth About Politician-Criminal Nexus 'Encountered'?
snippet.description:
Gangster Vikas Dubey was killed in an encounter after a road accident on Friday morning, while being taken to Kanpur in Uttar Pradesh. A lot of questions have also been raised over the UP Police's version. His death has now sparked off a political debate. Leaders from several political parties have raised questions at the encounter, wondering if it was orchestrated to prevent Dubey from revealing too much. From Mayawati and Akhilesh Yadav to Priyanka Gandhi and Manoj Jha, cutting across party lines, the demand is for a serious probe.

snippet.title: Enemy Saw Your Fire And Fury: PM To Soldiers At Ladakh
snippet.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday addressed soldiers in Ladakh on a surprise visit that served as a morale booster for the forces and sent a powerful message to China after the June 15 clash in the Galwan Valley. Addressing the troops in Nimu in Ladakh, PM Modi said the enemy had seen your fire and fury.

snippet.title: ‘Should Get Vaccine Out In 2 Years': Adar Poonawalla
snippet.description:
As the government's response and public concern over the coronavirus is increasing, the medical community is looking at two aspects. First, how much testing is optimal - should we expand it beyond at-risk populations to flatten the disease curve, or does mass testing burden the healthcare system? Second, where do India and other countries stand in developing a vaccine? People are expecting a vaccine for the coronavirus pandemic. Adar Poonawalla, CEO of Serum Institute of India, the world's largest vaccine manufacturer, answers concerns over vaccines.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Janata Curfew: Trial For Future?
snippet.description:
Some health experts have said that the actual number of cases in India could be many times more than what is now being reported. The central focus is this - as India gets set for the first day of what some say is a trial lockdown on Sunday, can the country truly delay the spread of this infection to a larger community? This will be the difference in potentially saving thousands of lives. If the coronavirus becomes a community wide transmission, people may never be able to locate and isolate the source of the infection.

snippet.title: India Fights Coronavirus
snippet.description:
India is fighting back the coronavirus. There is a robust system in place to ensure surveillance is maintained on those who may have come in contact with those who have contracted the virus. Other key steps are being taken. The remaining two ODIs against South Africa have been called off and the IPL has been postponed. In some states, schools have been shut and there are strong steps to discourage travel. After banning visas, the centre has given itself special powers to override states on matters of health to be able to tackle the outbreak countrywide. Tonight, we ask what powers does this give the central government and state government to deal with this and also if there has been any development on vaccines or cure?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Coronavirus Declared A Pandemic By World Health Organisation
snippet.description:
As the numbers of COVID-19 patients continue to soar around the world, we try and understand what this means for millions of Indians, across different walks of life. This is a special episode of The Big Fight where we look at this almost unbelievable crisis, something that's almost out of a thriller, except this is in real life and quite frightening. And why is that the case? Because COVID-19 is many times more contagious than the seasonal flu, because there is no cure, and because the rate at which the infection is doubling makes this one of the greatest challenges that nations have ever faced. The situation in several Western European countries is bleak and the impact on various parts of our economy could be catastrophic. This is why the World Health Organisation has dubbed this a global pandemic.

snippet.description:
On The Big Fight, we discuss the Yes Bank crisis. Amid reports of the SBI and the LIC stepping in to buy stake in the beleaguered bank, Gurcharan Das, former CEO of P&G India, raises morals questions around bailing out investors of Yes Bank with money from depositors and investors of SBI. Former ANZ Grindlays India manager, Biswajit Bhattacharya, raises questions on why should massive indian assets like SBI and LIC be weakened to bail out a private bank?

snippet.title: Delhi Violence: From Courts To Police, No Hope For Victims?
snippet.description:
As the number of dead and injured climbs up steadily in the aftermath of over four days of violence in Northeast Delhi last week, questions are being raised on the efficacy of India's public institutions. Controversy surrounds the role of the Delhi police and the midnight transfer of a Delhi High Court judge soon after passing a tough order. On the Big Fight, we discuss, is Delhi the symptom of a larger malaise? Have India's institutions failed its citizens?  And in such a scenario, what can clash victims hope for?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | 'Namo'ste Trump: Opportunity Or Optics?
snippet.description:
Ahead of US President Donald Trump’s maiden visit to India, we discuss how both nations that have long claimed a history of shared values, can further strengthen their ties, especially with Trump administration signalling no conclusive trade deal for the moment. We also look beyond the much hyped Namaste Trump event in Ahmedabad that many say is indicative of how strong personalities of both PM Modi and President Donald Trump have changed the way politics plays out at such bilateral events and discuss the changing nature of Indo-US relationship over the years.

snippet.title: Mehbooba Mufti's Daughter Iltija On Secret Notes To Mother
snippet.description:
"Words escape me to describe the past 6 months, I'll never forget the week she was arrested and jailed. I spent the next few days riddled with anxiety until I received a crumpled and tersely worded note, the first of many furtively exchanged letters. I found it in a tiffin box that contained home cooked food sent for her, soon a dilemma of dispatching a reply arose. My grandmother found an ingenious solution. The letter I wrote was folded into a tiny square and carefully sealed rolled and locked inside the middle of a chapatti," says Mehbooba Mufti's daughter Iltija.

I found it in a tiffin box that contained home cooked food sent for her, soon a dilemma of dispatching a reply arose. My grandmother found an ingenious solution. The letter I wrote was folded into a tiny square and carefully sealed rolled and locked inside the middle of a chapatti," says Mehbooba Mufti's daughter Iltija.

snippet.title: BJP Had No Issues With Mehbooba Mufti's Stand When They Had An Alliance, Says Her Daughter
snippet.description:
"Statements attributed to Omar Abdullah by the PM were never said, they have been taken straight from a fake news website. I find it alarming that when PM decides to talk about the issue on the floor of the parliament after six months, he decides to portray all three ex-Chief Ministers as anti-nationals. This is the same Mehbooba Mufti that the BJP had an alliance with. BJP had no issues with her stand when they wanted power in Jammu and Kashmir and today all of a sudden they wake up and they realise she was against abrogation of Article 370?", says Mehbooba Mufti's daughter Iltija.

snippet.title: Omar Abdullah, Mehbooba Mufti Slapped With PSA: Violation Of Democracy Or Essential For 'Normalcy'?
snippet.description:
Omar Abdullah and Mehbooba Mufti have been slapped with the stringent Public Safety Act which means the two former Chief Ministers can be detained for an extended period of time. On The Big Fight, we ask by slapping the stringent Public Safety Act against Omar Abdullah and Mehbooba Mufti, is the centre guaranteeing normalcy in the state or is this, in fact, a violation of democracy in Jammu and Kashmir? NDTV spoke exclusively to the daughter of Mehbooba Mufti, Iltija on the latest move by the government on the three former chief ministers of J&K.

On The Big Fight, we ask, can India regain its economic appetite?

snippet.title: Republic At 70: Is India's Democracy In Danger? | The Big Fight
snippet.description:
Over the last few months, beginning with the government's actions in Kashmir to the CAA, now India's democratic credentials are being questioned. This week, India slipped 10 places on a key world democracy index and The Economist has a cover story on India 'intolerant', while billionaire George Soros has made scathing comments on what he says is India becoming a Hindu nationalist state. The BJP may say it doesn't care what foreign publications write but they go out of their way to highlight positive coverage and the Prime Minister himself has written editorial pieces for the New York times which has been extremely critical of his government recently. On The Big Fight, we ask: Is India's democracy really in danger?

snippet.title: Founders Of Constitution Would Have Hailed Students: Gopalkrishna Gandhi
snippet.description:
"Our students, the younger generation, have shown us the way that Gandhi, Netaji, and all the founders of our constitution would have hailed for two reasons - one that they have shown tremendous confidence and two they have tried to be almost always successfully to remain completely non-violent, therefore constitutional. Many of the students and protesters may not have read the constitution but they capture its spirit, capture the soul of our constitution which guarantees several things like freedom of thought and expression, faith, belief and worship. It is important for us to know one thing that the preamble to the constitution is the soul of the constitution, it does not mention the Indian state, it only mentions the people", said Gopalkrishna Gandhi, Former Governor of West Bengal and Grandson of Mahatma Gandhi.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Crackdown On Dissent: Democracy In Descent?
snippet.description:
For more than a month now we have seen protests across India against the CAA and the NRC. Some of these protests began violently but most settled down into peaceful demonstrations, some have been hijacked by the political opposition, but what has been remarkable about many of them has been the lack of a leader, and the participation of women, of students, of ordinary people reading out the preamble to the Constitution reminding those who have forgotten what India really stands for. The Prime Minister talks about India's democracy - he said the Indian way of conflict avoidance is not by brute force but the power of dialogue, but where is his dialogue with the students who don't agree with his government?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Are Students The New Opposition?
snippet.description:
India is witnessing student protests across campuses for weeks now - from Jamia to JNU, from AMU to DU, from Madras University to Jadavpur in Bengal - India's students are standing up and speaking out and saying they have the right to express themselves in a democracy and they won't back down. But instead of reaching out to the students, what we have seen is the might of the Indian state coming down on them in full force - whether it was the police high handedness in Jamia to the attack by masked goons in JNU a few days ago. This violence has in fact lead to further protests, the protests which started as demonstrations against the CAA seem to have morphed into something else. Actor Deepika Padukone made a huge statement this week driving up to JNU and standing in solidarity with the students. Today union minister Smriti Irani attacked Deepika Padukone, saying she stood by the people who celebrate every time a CRPF jawan is killed. Today, the Delhi police who haven't arrested a single person for the JNU violence named some suspects. The violence in JNU came in two waves. The first - a group of students, some of them masked, entered JNU's Periyar Hostel around 3:45 pm on January 5. Seen in it, JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh. The second wave came later that night when a masked mob armed with weapons attacked Sabarmati Hostel, seemingly in retaliation to the first attack. The injures suffered in this second attack were serious: Aishe herself had head injuries, so did a Professor. Witnesses say the attack was led by the ABVP. But when the police today for the first time took names of the alleged JNU attackers, the tilt was against the Left. Of the nine people they named, seven are from the Left. One of them, Aishe Ghosh. Only two of nine named today are from the ABVP.

snippet.title: 6 Dead In Violence Across Uttar Pradesh During Citizenship Act Protests
snippet.description:
Six protesters were killed in clashes that erupted across Uttar Pradesh over the Citizenship Amendment Act on Friday, the state police confirmed. This has taken the total number of protest-related deaths in the state to seven so far. However, Uttar Pradesh Director General of Police OP Singh claimed that none of the protesters were killed in police firing. "We did not shoot even a single bullet," he said, even as another officer claimed that "if any firing happened, it was from the protesters' side".

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Citizenship Act: Fundamentally Changing India?
snippet.description:
It's been another tectonic week in India. A week that has seen parliament pass the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Bill 2019 that was signed into law by the President at midnight. The bill has opened two separate fronts in India. In the Northeast, there are concerns that 'outsiders' will take over their tradition, culture and livelihood. These concerns have sparked violent protests, particularly in Assam. On a bigger scale, across the country, not only Opposition parties but also many concerned citizens and even international community have flagged the concern about whether this bill actually runs contrary to the spirit of India's constitution. On The Big Fight, we debate: Is the new Citizenship Act going to fundamentally change India?

snippet.title: Is The Citizenship Test Constitutional?
snippet.description:
Next week, the BJP government will bring to parliament the controversial Citizenship Amendment Bill which will for the first time in India seek to grant people citizenship based on their religion. Combined with the National Register for Citizens, which aims to throw out illegal immigrants, the Citizenship bill could seriously deepen India's religious fault lines. On The Big Fight, we ask if the Citizenship Amendment Bill is constitutional or not?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Citizenship Test -Is It Constitutional?
snippet.description:
Next week, the BJP government will bring to parliament the controversial Citizenship Amendment Bill which will for the first time in India seek to grant people citizenship based on their religion. The bill clearly says that non-Muslim minorities who face religious persecution in Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan are eligible for Indian citizenship. After huge protests in the northeast, the BJP made changes this week. So that it does not apply to autonomous tribal-dominated regions in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram and also to states that have the inner-line permit regime (Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland and Mizoram). However, that may not be enough in Assam, many groups feel that the CAB will nullify the 1985 Assam Accord, which fixed March 24, 1971 as the cut-off date for deportation of all illegal immigrants irrespective of religion. These groups feel that the CAB will selectively benefit non-Muslim migrants into Assam combined with the NRC or the National Register for Citizens, which aims to throw out illegal immigrants. The Citizenship bill could seriously deepen India's religious faultlines.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Economy In ICU: Will Government's Growth Boosters Work?
snippet.description:
With the latest GDP numbers out at 4.5 per cent, the lowest since March 2013, it is clea that India's economy is in deep trouble. Car sales have gone down, factory output has shrunk, and exports have also slumped and the government's own data shows that rural spending has gone down, data the centre conveniently distanced itself from a couple of weeks ago. The government has tried to take steps to fix that in recent months and has slashed corporate taxes, set up a special real-estate fund, merged banks and announced the biggest privatization drive in more than a decade. While authorities are committed to doing more, the policy room may be narrowing. On The Big Fight , we ask with the economy in ICU, will government's growth boosters work?

snippet.title: Maharashtra Stunner: Phir Ek Baar, Fadnavis Sarkaar | The Big Fight
snippet.description:
In a move that has stunned everyone, BJP's Devendra Fadnavis quietly took oath as Maharashtra Chief Minister in the early hours this morning with the NCP's Ajit Pawar beside him taking oath as his deputy. Just 12 hours earlier, NCP chief Sharad Pawar had said Shiv Sena's Udhhav Thackeray was the choice for the chief minister's post after a meeting of the Congress-NCP and the Sena. On The Big Fight today, we look at all the twists and turns that are taking place in the political spectrum of Maharashtra.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Growth Forecast Down: Is Economy In Free Fall?
snippet.description:
Is India's economy in free fall? Growth numbers are down, industrial production is down, auto sales are also down, while new data shows poverty may have actually gone up. This week, India's largest public sector bank State Bank of India said Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth will slow down further to 4.2 per cent in the second quarter of this year, after it hit a six-year low of 5 per cent in the first quarter. SBI has also rolled back its forecasts for India's GDP growth for the current fiscal from 6.1 per cent earlier to just 5 per cent now. The telecom sector is facing a huge crisis, but there is some hope for them after indications that the government could step in to bail them out. A report in Business Standard newspaper showed that consumer spending has fallen in 2017-18 for the first time in more than four decades, primarily driven by slackening rural demand, which experts say points to a rise in poverty, according to data complied by the National Statistical Office (NSO).

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Smoke House Delhi: Are We Losing The War Against Pollution?
snippet.description:
There is an air emergency in North India as pollution levels are almost 13 times the safe limit. Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal describes it as a 'gas chamber' and orders the closure of all schools in Delhi till November 5 and distributes pollution masks in the city. In this special edition of The Big Fight, we decided to come out of the studio to discuss how critical the pollution level has become in the capital and why is it essential for us to talk about it and find a solution.

snippet.title: Maharashtra, Haryana Results: Has The Nationalism Card Run Its Course?
snippet.description:
The results are in for Maharashtra and Haryana but the story isn't over yet. In Maharashtra, the BJP's reduced numbers have made them more dependent on the Shiv Sena and the Sena is clearly playing hardball. In Haryana, the BJP will form the government with the help of Dushyant Chautala's JJP. The bigger question we ask on The Big Fight is: What do these polls tell us about what voters want, and which issues matter? The BJP campaigned aggressively on nationalist issues like Article 370 but that hasn't worked. With an economic crisis and other day-to-day issues affecting people more, does the nationalism card have its limits?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Local Issues Dead In Elections?
snippet.description:
The Haryana and Maharashtra state election campaigning could have been around a whole host of local issues. Economy, farmer distress, unemployment, drought, poverty, reservation for specific castes but what we have heard all through election campaigning is a discourse around the abrogation of Article 370 in Kashmir, implementation of Assam's NRC all over the country and only very recently ,the promise of giving Bharat Ratna to Vinayak Damodar Savarkar. The BJP has been winning elections on its own terms - challenging conventional campaigning wisdom. We find that even in many municipal elections, emotive issues like 370 has been spoken about, and in some cases, even worked. So on The Big Fight tonight, we ask just one simple question. Are local issues dead in elections? The problems may exist in real life, but do they simply not matter when voters go out and vote?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | PM Modi-Xi Jinping Meet: Can India Trust China?
snippet.description:
From Wuhan to Mamallapuram, it has been quite a journey for India and China over the last year. When Prime Minister Modi and President Xi Jinping met for their first informal summit in Wuhan in 2018, both countries struck the right tone, setting the stage for a good meeting. This year it has been quite different, with sharp words exchanged over Kashmir and Beijing hosting Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan on the eve of Xi's visit to India. The question we ask on The Big Fight is - can India and China find a middle ground in which to manage the relationship or does New Delhi need to be more realistic about dealing with China?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Corporate Tax Slashed To Spur Growth
snippet.description:
Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has reduced corporate tax on domestic firms from 35% to around 25, which includes all surcharges and is applicable on those companies that aren't availing any incentives. The announcement was immediately welcomed by corporate India and the stock markets, which surged over 2,100 points. The NSE Nifty climbed above the 11,250 mark, after days of choppy trading. While domestic companies have a lot to cheer about, the Finance Minister said she is "conscious" of the effect the announcement would have on India's fiscal deficit target. That's because this will cost the Centre Rs 1.45 lakh crores this fiscal. India Inc has welcomed the move, saying the most immediate impact will be improving the overall sentiment, allowing more cash in the hands of companies to re-invest in their capacities, and for investors - possibly better dividends.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Millennials And Math: New Threats To The Indian Economy?
snippet.description:
It is no secret now that India's economy is in deep trouble. The GDP is at 5 per cent, the lowest in over six years; auto sales are their lowest in over 20 years; rural wage growth has collapsed to 1 per cent in 2018-19 compared to 15 per cent in 2013-14; while unemployment is at a 45-year-high. But over the last week, much of the news has focused on the dreaded two Ms - Math and Millennials. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said the fact that millennials are using car apps like OLA and Uber is the reason car sales are down. She's got a lot of flak for it, simply because the data doesn't match her claims, and then why are truck sales also down? Then Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal said on Thursday how numbers don't matter, "after all Math didn't help Einstein discover gravity", but it did make Mr Goyal trend on Twitter all day. But that's not the point. People make mistakes. Yes, Issac Newton discovered gravity, not Albert Einstein. But the bigger point is: Is the government taking the economic slowdown as seriously as it should be? Is it time to put partisan politics aside, sit down with someone like Dr Manmohan Singh and try and find solutions?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is Assam NRC A Humanitarian Disaster?
snippet.description:
It has been a colossal exercise in attempting to weed out illegal immigrants from Assam, an exercise that was always riddled in controversy and chaos. The National Register of Citizens or the NRC, aimed at identifying illegals, was published last Saturday after five years of being monitored by the Supreme Court. With its publication, it became even clearer that the whole exercise had been a colossal mess. Nearly two million people have been excluded in the final list, facing the possibility of being rendered stateless. And politically, it's a huge irony: the BJP which has championed the NRC and even called for it to be replicated across India, is today shocked that the final list has a large number of Bengali Hindus in it, they're convinced that the numbers from the high population Muslim areas are not accurate.

snippet.title: Assam Citizens' List: Detention Crisis Looms?
snippet.description:
Over 19 lakh people, who have been excluded from Assam citizens' list, have 120 days to file their appeals. This means the tribunals will have to address an average of nearly 16,000 appeals per day. Is that practically feasible? "The legal process, going all the way to the Supreme Court, the cases will last for years. Where are these people going to go," asks former chairperson of National Commission on Minorities Wajahat Habibullah.

snippet.title: 'Tough Decision' on J&K: Change In Nuclear No-First Use Doctrine Next?
snippet.description:
Union Defence Minister Rajnath Singh today underscored that India reserves the right to change its policy of 'No First Use', which has been the cornerstone of India's nuclear weapons policy for decades. The government firmly stands by its 'No First Use' policy but "what happens in future will depend on the circumstances," the minister said at Pokhran in Rajasthan. The statement comes a day after the PM announced the creation of the post of Chief of Defence Staff. On The Big Fight, we discuss the consequences of making such statements in the current environment.

snippet.title: Can PM Modi's Outreach Bring Peace To J&K?
snippet.description:
A monumental decision that has changed the political landscape of Jammu and Kashmir - Article 370 rendered useless, the state being carved into two union territories - Jammu-Kashmir and Ladakh and then, on Thursday, a comprehensive explanation from Prime Minister Narendra Modi on why this has been necessary. As Jammu and Kashmir moves towards normalcy with restrictions being gradually removed, we look at what the Prime Minister said and ask whether the economic outreach that he has proposed has the potential to transform a state that has seen so much suffering for so long.

localized.title: Can PM Modi's Outreach Bring Peace To J&K?
localized.description:
A monumental decision that has changed the political landscape of Jammu and Kashmir - Article 370 rendered useless, the state being carved into two union territories - Jammu-Kashmir and Ladakh and then, on Thursday, a comprehensive explanation from Prime Minister Narendra Modi on why this has been necessary. As Jammu and Kashmir moves towards normalcy with restrictions being gradually removed, we look at what the Prime Minister said and ask whether the economic outreach that he has proposed has the potential to transform a state that has seen so much suffering for so long.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Is There More Outrage Against Those Raising Voice Against Mob Killings?
snippet.description:
Earlier this week, the state of Rajasthan introduced a bill that proposes a tough new law to deal with incidents of mob killings. As per the bill, if the victim dies due to mob violence, people guilty of the crime will be given life sentences. Also, conspiracy to lynch will be treated as a crime equal to lynching itself. Is there less outrage over the lynchings and more at those who protest them? We discuss on The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | NRC: Anti-Illegal Immigrants Or Anti-Muslim?
snippet.description:
This week, the Supreme Court extended by one month its deadline for a National Citizen's Register to be completed by the government in Assam. It will now have to be done by August 31. The exercise, which is taking place only in Assam for now, was put on the fast track by the top court in 2015. It aims to weed out illegal immigrants and ensure only genuine Indian citizens reside in the state. But the process of the NRC has been deeply flawed  from the start. The basic premise of putting the onus on individuals to prove their citizenship has been problematic. People have to produce documents to show that they are genuine citizens and not everyone has that paperwork. There are over four million people who have currently been excluded from the list and they have a right to appeal to foreigner tribunals and then the courts. If all these options fail, they can be jailed in detention centres, but some of the examples of those excluded has been jarring - like a former armyman who is currently out on bail after being excluded from the list. Critics say the BJP has decided to make Muslims the real target. They point out that it is no coincidence that the government has a bill ready which will exclude only Muslim immigrants from neighbouring countries to seek refuge in India. The BJP denies this; the government says the exercise is only aimed at illegals. But the story is no longer about Assam. Home Minister Amit Shah has declared in parliament that illegal immigrants from every inch of India will be thrown out. So what is the NRC really about? Is it anti-illegal immigrants or anti-Muslim?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Is India More Casteist Than Ever Before?
snippet.description:
This week, the video of a young woman went viral on social media, in which she was pleading with her powerful politician father to back off and stop threatening her for marrying a man from a scheduled caste. The story of Sakshi Misra and her husband Ajitesh is right out of a bad Bollywood film - her father is a BJP lawmaker from UP, her husband Ajitesh was beaten up in the Allahabad High Court the other day - but it's a story that also represents the very cruel reality of caste in India. Our leaders often make big proclamations that India's caste divide is narrowing, that caste is slowly beginning to matter less in the way people vote, but is that true? When Mr Modi won his massive mandate in May, he said in his victory speech that "Only two castes will remain in this country: the poor and those who contribute whatever little to free the country from poverty." But is that narrative reflective of the reality on the ground? On the other hand, politically, the emergence of leaders like Chandrasheker Azad, who have challenged the BJP's brand of politics has also created a stir, but has it really made an impact? In this new India, is caste discrimination more entrenched than ever before?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Are We Heading For One-Party Rule?
snippet.description:
What a week this has been. The Congress-JDS government in Karnataka is hanging by a thread. The congress has also seen a spectacular collapse in Goa, losing 10 of its 15 MLAs to the BJP, and in Delhi, the party has no clue who its leader is after Rahul Gnadhi's resignation. Seven weeks after the election results, the country's grand old party is facing an existential crisis. Then there are the regional parties who enjoyed a dominant role in the coalition era before 2014 and seemed to be giving the BJP the only real fight state-by-state. But look at their situation today. After winning just five seats in UP, Akhilesh Yadav, the head of the party, disappeared and went abroad, only to return to India earlier this week. Lalu Yadav's RJD, under his son Tejwaswi, got zero seats in Bihar - a first for the party which has been a powerful regional force. Tejwasi has been AWOL most of the last few weeks as well. Maywati didn't do that much better in UP, with 10 seats. Chandrababu Naidu's TDP is also unravelling quickly - four of his six Rajya Sabha MPs joined the BJP. The only parties that withstood the Modi wave were the DMK, the BJD, the TRS, and to some extent Mamata Banerjee's Trinamool Congress, but here too, the TMC is facing a strong challenge ahead of the Bengal state polls. Even the BJD isn't comfortable - they did well in the assembly poll but the BJP did well in the Lok Sabha election. With this massive mandate for PM Modi, and what seems to be an opposition that is withering away, are we heading towards one-party rule?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are India's Minorities Living In Fear?
snippet.description:
When Prime Minister Narendra Modi talked about sabka vishwas, soon after his re-election last month, many believed he was making a real effort to reach out to minorities. That perhaps, this massive mandate could see a change in the way minorities, read Muslims, are looked at and dealt with by the ruling establishment. But this past week, the headlines have been dominated by the haunting video of a 24-year-old Muslim man who was beaten up brutally by a mob in Jharkhand on the suspicion of stealing a motorcycle. Disturbing videos show him being forced to chant slogans of Jai Shri Ram and Jai Hanuman. This year alone there have been 11 hate crimes in India and almost all the victims have been Muslim. Look at Parliament, in the world's largest democracy, where almost 200 million people are Muslims, there are only 27 Muslim MPs and none of them are from the BJP. Do these hate crimes and the disproportionate representation of Muslims mean that minorities have a reason to live in fear or are those fears exaggerated?

Disturbing videos show him being forced to chant slogans of Jai Shri Ram and Jai Hanuman. This year alone there have been 11 hate crimes in India and almost all the victims have been Muslim. Look at Parliament, in the world's largest democracy, where almost 200 million people are Muslims, there are only 27 Muslim MPs and none of them are from the BJP. Do these hate crimes and the disproportionate representation of Muslims mean that minorities have a reason to live in fear or are those fears exaggerated?

snippet.title: One Nation, One Election: Practical Or Advantage BJP?
snippet.description:
It was supposed to have been the Prime Minister's first big effort at reaching out to the opposition after the new government was sworn in. But, the meeting called to look at the implementation of 'one nation, one election' turned out to be a flop with several opposition parties choosing not to attend. The elections are over, but some would say the simmering discontent within the opposition lingers - others would say regional parties are trying to protect their turf , while still others would say big national parties like the BJP have all to gain at the expense of smaller opposition parties. As we start this episode of The Big Fight, here is a fact that not many may be aware of: The first general elections to the Lok Sabha and all State Legislative Assemblies were held together in 1951-52. That practice continued over three subsequent general elections held in the years - 1957, 1962 and 1967.

snippet.title: Are India's GDP Growth Numbers A Myth?
snippet.description:
One of the biggest headlines in the last few days has been about whether India genuinely has the GDP growth rate that the government says we do. Arvind Subramanian, the former Chief Economic Advisor to the government, has, in article, said that India wasn't growing at 7 per cent. It was growing at about 4.5 per cent. Mr Subramanian says no political motives can be ascribed to his study which he has down at Harvard in the US. Now, the government has responded - they've said India follows meticulous standards in coming out with data. But let's look all around us - the job numbers indicate a slowdown. The auto sector, a huge contributor to GDP is in deep trouble and more than 100 experts have said that there is something wrong with the data that India is generating.

snippet.title: Is Referendum 2019 A Referendum On PM Modi?
snippet.description:
The bitter, personal campaign for 2019 elections is over, and the question that arises now is finally, when all the votes are cast, what would have the people of India based their decision on. Is it the economy? Jobs? National security? Or just Narendra Modi. PM Modi's personality has loomed large over this election which many believe has simply been a referendum on him. Tonight, on 'The Big Fight', we ask: Is referendum 2019 a referendum on PM Modi, like the famous Time magazine cover says is he India's divider in chief or a great unifier?

snippet.title: "Whether It's Pak Or…": Tejasvi Surya's Heated Debate With Prakash Raj On NDTV's Big Fight
snippet.description:
BJP leader Tejasvi Surya and actor-turned-politician Prakash Raj on Friday entered into a heated argument on NDTV show "The Big Fight". They were debating on the issue of personal attacks in the political narrative. Mr Surya, BJP candidate from Bengaluru Central constituency, was defending Prime Minister Narendra Modi in the debate when he said his party will " teach you in the language you understand, whether it is Pakistan or Prakash Raj". Former AAP leader Ashutosh, who was also present on the show, took exception to the comment. Prakash Raj said there was no need for PM Modi to reply in the same way even if he is attacked.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Is The Election Commission's Credibility Still Intact?
snippet.description:
Battleground 2019 has turned out to be a bitter campaign among the contesting parties, but this is an election that will also be remembered for how the Election Commission has conducted itself. The Election Commission has been one of India's most respected institutions but today it finds itself at the heart of scathing criticism. They acted against some political leaders for violating the model code of conduct only after a strong rebuke from the Supreme Court. But after a series of complaints against the PM for violating the model code, PM Modi has got a clean in six cases. Four out of these have seen dissent by one election commissioner. On the show tonight, we ask has the poll panel lost its credibility?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | PM's Presidential Pitch: Is It Advantage Modi?
snippet.description:
On The Big Fight, we discuss with more than half the Parliament seats having voted now, and with  four phases left, who has the edge in this campaign? Has this election now become almost completely about Narendra Modi rather than a seat-by-seat fight? And does that give Mr Modi the advantage? Joining us on the show, Congress communication in charge Randeep Surjewala says that PM has nothing to show for his five years of work, while actor Richa Chadha says the PM should hold a press conference and take questions on jobs and agrarian crisis. BJP's Vivek Reddy responds by saying that when the opposition only talks about PM Modi he responds accordingly. This and much more on The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | BJP's Goodbye To 'Vikas', Hello To Hindutva?
snippet.description:

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Battle Of Alliances: Who Has The Edge?
snippet.description:
Tonight on the Big Fight Road to 2019, we discuss the big question: Is the NDA alliance led by the BJP trying to make the Lok Sabha elections presidential? Is the BJP trying to push the narrative towards national security rather than issues like jobs, agrarian crisis affecting the economy and also with less than two weeks to go for polling, has the BJP got its alliance arithmetic right while the Congress is yet to tick some boxes?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Race For Alliances: NDA Leads UPA?
snippet.description:
The biggest battle of India democracy is upon us, election dates have been announced and Battleground 2019 will be the battle between NDA 3.0 and UPA 3.0 and at the moment it seems to be the BJP-led NDA which is leading the race in stitching up alliances. Mahua Moitra, Trinamool spokesperson says that it is battle for the idea of India and if opposition parties don't get their act together there might be no constitution by 2024. KC Tyagi, senior leader of the JDU, says that NDA is a settled alliance and in a key state like Bihar, the BJP-JDU alliance has a definitive edge. Ghanshyam Tiwari of the Samajwadi Party believes that in the most important state of UP, the SP-BSP-RLD grand alliance is set to win and it is for Congress to work out its strategy. On The Big Fight 2019, we ask, who is leading the alliance race.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | India-Pak Tensions: What Is The Road Ahead For India?
snippet.description:
Wing Commander Abhinandan's return has marked, at least temporarily, a pause in escalating hostilities between India and Pakistan after the Pulwama terror attack and India's air strikes on a Jaish camp in Pakistan. On The Big Fight, we ask the question what are India's options? Former Foreign Secretary Nirupama Rao joining us on the show tonight that India must continue to step up diplomatic pressure, whereas former chief of R&AW A S Dulat believes that the government's policy towards Pakistan must be consistent.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Battle Of 'Gathbandhans'
snippet.description:
Tonight on The Big Fight Road To 2019, we discuss how the BJP which termed the grand alliance as 'Maha-Milavat' is in fact stitching up a grand alliance of its own, firstly by joining hands with old friend turned foe, now friend again Shiv Sena in Maharashtra and the AIADMK in Tamil Nadu. The question now arises: Is the BJP feeling the heat in lead up to polls or has it accepted the ground reality of coalition compulsions? Joining on the show is Shiv Sena MP Arvind Sawant who says that the alliance will repeat its stellar 2014 show but this time around focus will be on 'equal distribution of power'.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Pulwama Attack: How Should India React?
snippet.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi had warned that those behind the terror attack in Pulwama which killed over 40 CRPF soldiers would pay a "very heavy price" and we now know that besides diplomatic measures military options are also being considered. On this episode of The Big fight, we try to find out from experts, what should be India's response in the aftermath of this horrific terror attack and what next for India-Pakistan ties.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Will BJP And Shiv Sena Bury The Hatchet?
snippet.description:
Tonight, on The Big Fight Road to 2019, we discuss the state of Maharashtra, next only to Uttar Pradesh in terms of Lok Sabha seats. Will BJP and Sena bury the hatchet or go their own ways? On the show we ask this question to Sena MP Avind Sawant and BJP's Shaina NC because it will be the key to the big fight in 2019

Tonight, on The Big Fight Road to 2019, we discuss the state grabbing all the headlines this week, West Bengal - a state which is absolutely vital to the BJP's Lok Sabha strategy in general elections with its 42 seats. snippet.title: The Big Fight | Akhilesh Yadav-Mayawati Tie Up: The Perfect Alliance?
snippet.description:
Tonight on the Road to 2019, we discuss the political implications of the Mayawati-Akhilesh Yadav alliance in Uttar Pradesh. We break down the numbers and see why Mayawati says this alliance will give BJP sleepless nights, and even by doing projections based on the 'Modi Wave' election of 2014 this alliance can wipe out BJP's then 71 seats almost by half. Also on the show tonight, we talk exclusively to former Delhi chief minister Sheila Dikshit who is back as Delhi Congress chief on Congress prospects in Delhi, alliance with AAP and the controversy around Jagdish Tytler being seen in front row at the event where she returned to active Delhi politics.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | How Will Citizenship And Quota Bills Impact BJP's Prospects In 2019 Polls?
snippet.description:
Tonight on the Big Fight - Road to 2019, we discuss the implications of the two big bills passed by parliament - the 10 per cent quota bill for the general category and the citizenship amendment bill passed by Lok Sabha. Former Assam chief minister and ex-BJP ally AGP's Founding President Prafulla Mahanta says that there is massive unrest against the citizenship bill and it will have massive impact across the north-east. On the show, we ask, how will these two bills impact BJP's prospects in 2019 elections and eventually the political situation of India?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: The Credibility Crisis In India's Institutions
snippet.description:
On this episode of The Big Fight, we look at the overall question of institutional integrity. The concept of other institutions becoming agents of the government was never a good idea. Institutional independence and integrity is one of the cornerstones of any democracy. If the rule of the law were to really operate, then we have to follow some checks and balances. Today, we look at all that's happening right now and discuss the ways to stop this.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Attacks On Migrants - No Unity In Diversity?
snippet.description:
A large number of people moving to live and work in other places often leads to a flashpoint. We saw an example of this recently in Gujarat, where thousands of migrants had to flee fearing mob violence, and in Assam over the National Register of Citizens. On this episode of The Big Fight we discuss the migration issue and to what extent is it going to become a major flashpoint.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Has India Finally Found Its #MeToo Moment?
snippet.description:
As more and more women share their accounts of sexual harassment and abuse exposing many big names in Bollywood, on The Big Fight, we debate -  is this Bollywood's watershed moment? With organisations like the Cine And TV Artistes Association investigating complaints and Producers Guild setting up a special committee to help #MeToo survivors, a change is surely visible but will it have far-reaching implications for workplaces and gender-sensitivity across the country? Is it enough to jolt society out of a place of power and entitlement, to provide women what they deserve or is it just lip service that the industry is offering to weather the storm?

snippet.title: Indian Youth: Neither Left Nor Right?
snippet.description:
This has been an interesting week in the world of politics where all sorts of statements on ideology have come. The left sweeping JNU elections and the right taking the Delhi University, bring an interesting question to mind. Are the youth really politically motivated and involved right now. The youth vote is very crucial for the upcoming elections. On this episode of The Big Fight, we discuss what's going to drive the youth vote, are the youth today essentially interested in other things? Or there is still a political or ideological connect?

snippet.title: Has India Finally Become A Multi-Sport Nation?
snippet.description:
Has India arrived on the sporting stage? On one hand, India is said to have the best Test cricket team, a claim captain Virat Kohli stands by even after a 1-4 drubbing in the recently-concluded series in England. On the other hand is India's best-ever medal haul at the Asian Games 2018, including many non-conventional sports like sepak takraw and heptathlon. On the Big Fight, we debate whether the recent Test series performance by India is an aberration, with so many athletes bringing in medals in lesser-known sports. Have we finally moved on to becoming a multi-sport nation, focussing on sports other than cricket?

localized.title: Has India Finally Become A Multi-Sport Nation?
localized.description:
Has India arrived on the sporting stage? On one hand, India is said to have the best Test cricket team, a claim captain Virat Kohli stands by even after a 1-4 drubbing in the recently-concluded series in England. On the other hand is India's best-ever medal haul at the Asian Games 2018, including many non-conventional sports like sepak takraw and heptathlon. On the Big Fight, we debate whether the recent Test series performance by India is an aberration, with so many athletes bringing in medals in lesser-known sports. Have we finally moved on to becoming a multi-sport nation, focussing on sports other than cricket?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is Karl Marx Still Relevant?
snippet.description:
On this episode of The Big Fight, we remember all that has happened 200 years since the birth of German philosopher and economist Karl Marx, considered the father of communism. It's time to take stock of a couple of things. Was Marxism wrong? Was Karl Marx wrong? Has it failed completely? The Left movement in India is facing the worst time that it has faced in memories. Is it a permanent decline for left ideology?

snippet.title: What Does Imran Khan As Pakistan PM Mean For India
snippet.description:
In his 'victory speech', Pakistan's new Prime Minister Imran Khan sent a curt message that he should not be portrayed as a "Bollywood villain" in India and that talks are the best way forward for lasting peace between the two biggest countries of the sub-continent. While the emphasis on dialogue with India is a positive signal, security analysts warn against premature celebrations. On The Big Fight, we debate whether Imran Khan's promise of a 'Naya Pakistan' also means renewed hope for Indo-Pak ties. There are genuine concerns in India that for all his vision of peace and prosperity, the cricketer-turned-politician could just end up as a puppet Prime Minister in the hands of the country's miliatry which, in turn, could mean status-quo with India - or worse.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Dalit Protests And BJP's Caste Conundrum
snippet.description:
The question of Dalit outrage has been a talking point over the last few months now. A big Dalit bandh that was called for, has been provisionally called off. What exactly is the government planning to do with the question of Dalit anger? Is there going to be a backlash from other communities? What's going to happen to the OBC commission itself? We discuss some of these issues and their impact.

snippet.title: What Next For The 40 Lakh Left Out In Assam Citizen's List?
snippet.description:
The final draft of the National Register of Citizens released in Assam has left 40 lakh people in limbo about the status of their citizenship. This week, the NRC also dominated the discourse in parliament with BJP president Amit Shah asking all parties to clarify their stand on illegal immigrants. Citizenship for Bangladeshi immigrants has become a political hot potato in the context of the already existing polarisation in the country. In this episode of The Big Fight, we discuss, what next for those who are not able to prove their citizenship over the next three months.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Will Anti-Lynching Law Work?
snippet.description:
In the wake of a number of incidents mob violence, the Supreme Court has suggested that a  new law be enacted specifically to deal with the "new normal" of lynchings. But doubts remain about the efficacy of the proposed solution. On The Big Fight, we debate whether a new law is the solution. The judgment places the onus on the law and order machinery to prevent and punish lynchings but can a new law work if there is lack of political will to tackle the lynch mobs?

snippet.title: 2019: One Nation, One Poll?
snippet.description:
PM Modi and the Niti Aayog have been pushing the case for simultaneous elections to be held all across the country in a bid to overhaul the electoral system and to save the huge amount of money that is spent in conducting elections. According to the Niti Aayog, on an average there are five to seven elections annually which leads to disruption of governance and loss of a great amount of time and money. While many agree that conducting Lok Sabha and State assembly elections simultaneously will be a good idea, no clear road map as to how this concept should be implemented has come up. The consultations conducted by Law Commission this past week saw parties divided over the issue. On The Big Fight, we debate whether 'One nation, one poll' is indeed a good idea and whether it will prove to be PM Modi's political masterstroke for 2019.

snippet.title: Emergency Of 1975: Lessons In Democracy
snippet.description:
The Emergency of 1975 was discussed across political circles throughout this week. Questions have been asked about what the future holds, and whether such an event would ever happen in India again. Democratic institutions got top priority in the discussions. A panel discusses the Emergency at length and the lessons that people of the country must keep in mind from the event 43 years ago. To maintain eternal vigilance and ensure that democratic institutions remain safe have been the thrust of the discussions and debates.

snippet.title: Governor's Rule In Jammu And Kashmir: Masterstroke By BJP?
snippet.description:
Jammu and Kashmir has seen fast political developments in the last one week, after the BJP ended the alliance with the PDP of Mehbooba Mufti. BJP president Amit Shah also addressed a rally in Jammu on Saturday, where he iterated the party's vision of putting development first before politics. There were battles on Twitter and some BJP legislators had also given bizarre statements. We take a look at what the future holds for the state, from security issues to politics.

snippet.title: Constitutional Crisis In Delhi: Arvind Kejriwal-Lt Governor At Loggerheads
snippet.description:
Delhi is witnessing an unprecedented showdown between the Lieutenant Governor and the Chief Minister, resulting in the Chief Minister of Delhi sitting on a dharna - on a sofa. Arvind Kejriwal is trying to get the city to move again, the Lt Governor has his own position and the IAS officers also seem to be on some sort of a strike. In the middle of everything, Delhi is quite not functioning. Amidst this, a demand for Delhi's statehood has been raised and as politics would have it so is the resistance towards it. So, Delhi is facing a constitutional crisis. Whatever be the immediate politics, these are long term issues, long term questions which need to be addressed.

snippet.title: Poll Of Exit Polls Shows Hung House In Karnataka, BJP Largest
snippet.description:
Karnataka could return a split verdict with the BJP as the single largest party and former Prime Minister HD Deve Gowda a kingmaker, an aggregate of nine exit polls show. But the exit polls were deeply divided on the outcome -- five of them predicting that the BJP will be the single largest party. Two of them suggested that there is an outside chance that the party will gain majority.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is Press Freedom Under Threat In India?
snippet.description:
On The Big Fight, we talk about the free press. There are a couple of parameters under which we discuss it, first - government's crackdown on the press, secondly the safety of journalists - which is a cause of worry and finally, the need for media to introspect on the quality of news. Why is there an erosion? It should be a fundamental feature of our democracy to be committed to the freedom of press. Free journalism, accurate journalism and journalism that operates without fear from anybody.

snippet.title: Are 'Godmen' Above The Law Of The Land?
snippet.description:
The big story that hit the headlines this week was the conviction of self-styled godman Asaram in a case involving the sexual assault of a minor at his ashram in 2013. Asaram Bapu was sentenced to life imprisonment by the Jodhpur court. While reports of sexual assaults continue to pour in from across the country, the ones that have provoked massive outrage were incidents of rapes that occurred in a place of worship. The question that begs to be answered is what gives a "god-person" the right to violate someone and get away with it? As a few "god-persons" freely exercises their authority and influence over unsuspecting devotees, is this behaviour encouraged by the political patronage they receive? Does that make a "god-person" above the law? Should not all men and "god-men" be equal in the eyes of the law? What gives them impunity from the law of the land?

As a few "god-persons" freely exercises their authority and influence over unsuspecting devotees, is this behaviour encouraged by the political patronage they receive? Does that make a "god-person" above the law? Should not all men and "god-men" be equal in the eyes of the law? What gives them impunity from the law of the land?

snippet.title: Does India Have A 'Rape Problem'?
snippet.description:
Public anger over rapes this week forced the government to take new steps towards addressing the problem.  As one went through graphic details of the assault on children as young as 8 months old, we ask whether India has a 'rape problem'. Is it because of this over arching patriarchal society that we live in, or can it be attributed to the fact that the conviction rate in the case of rape is abysmally low. The government, through an ordinance, hopes to toughen rape laws by raising the minimum punishment for rape from 7 to 10 years. The law will also set a deadline to investigating a rape case. For raping children under 12 years of age, the order allows for the judge to order death penalty to the convict. Will death penalty act as a deterrent to curb these horrific crimes? Experts are of the view that that may prove to be counterproductive as it may endanger the life of the rape victim. With a problem this grave, there are no easy answers here. What is clear however, that women's and children's safety should the priority of the government and stringent preventive action needs to be taken.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Government Tackling Fake News Or Muzzling The Press?
snippet.description:
It has been a busy week for journalists around the country as the government came out with a controversial order stating that journalists stand a chance to lose accreditation if they create or circulate 'fake news'. The order led to enormous backlash by the journalistic community that saw the move as a way to muzzle the press. The Modi government was quick to react, as the circular was revoked on the orders of the Prime Minister. However later in the week, there was another controversial announcement over the formation of a committee to regulate online news, with not a single member from the platform to represent them. Could this be seen as an attempt by the government to keep a tab on online content? Is it better for the media to be its own watchdog? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight and write in to us at bigfight@ndtv.com with your comments and suggestions

snippet.title: Is Higher Education In A Mess?
snippet.description:
Exam leaks are not new to India, but has it been particularly bad this year as the first quarter of the year has been marred by exam leaks and student protests in some of the most prestigious teaching institutions in the country. The question of education is back in news and we ask, shouldn't a crisis in education be on the agenda for the government? Is there something fundamentally wrong with higher education in India? Is it in dire need of reform? Does it need private funding? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Right To Die With Dignity
snippet.description:
In a recent verdict, the Supreme Court stated that the Right to Die with Dignity is a fundamental right of every individual, as an extension, it legalised passive euthanasia and approved a 'living will' or an advanced directive for terminally ill patients or those in an incurable vegetative state. The verdict which upheld individual rights was lauded by activists, but not everyone is happy since it poses larger spiritual, philosophical, religious and practical questions. Once made into a law, is this freedom likely to me misused? Will it put undue pressure on the medical fraternity? What about the contentious clause in the government's draft bill that allows for anyone over the age of 16 years to opt for passive euthanasia? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Does Our History Need Correcting?
snippet.description:
The government under the leadership of the Culture Minister Mahesh Sharma has constituted a committee to rewrite India's ancient history. It is the government's intention to trace the history of the country back to 12,000 years and 'fill the gaps' created by earlier historians who the government feels, may have carried a bias. On the show, we debate whether history can be written without an ideological tilt? Will this attempt to 'rewrite' history by the government, ignore facts while supporting a certain stand point? Should the government get involved in how the history of a country is written or should this be the exclusive mandate of social scientists and academicians? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Dawn Of The Age Of Artificial Intelligence
snippet.description:
It is something that impacts our day-to-day life, as we search for traffic free routes on our phones, or play a game of chess 'with the computer' or search for the coolest restaurant to visit - but how often do we actually think about 'artificial intelligence'. On this special episode of The Big Fight, we look at the role that artificial intelligence will play in our future, the sectors that will rely on it heavily, what the government will need to do to regulate it and if there should be laws to govern AI? Is there much more to AI than what is depicted in popular culture? Should we guard against the possible misuse of this artificial intelligence or take it as an ally in civilizational development? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight and share your thoughts with us on bigfight@ndtv.com

snippet.title: Should Non-State Groups Like RSS Assist The Army?
snippet.description:
Widely regarded as the ideological big brother of the BJP, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh's clout over the government has been increasing since the BJP government came to power. In a recent controversy, the RSS Chief Mohan Bhagwat appeared to suggest that the organisation could be deployed to defend the nation faster than the army. The RSS later clarified that the organisation was by no means undermining the army but was stating that their disciplined lifestyle offers them an edge when it comes to military action. On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we try and debate the various interpretations of the RSS chief's statement while also looking at the organisations' journey from a cultural one to one that actively engages in politics and governance.

snippet.title: Maldives Crisis: A Mega Battle For Regional Influence?
snippet.description:
The tiny island nation of Maldives made waves across the world this week after President Abdulla Yameen declared a state emergency and took political prisoners including members of the judiciary who took him on over the prosecution of political opponents. The Supreme Court of Maldives appealed for India to step in to resolve this situation but India is yet to respond to the crisis. Is it time for New Delhi to step up its diplomacy to curb the increasing Chinese influence in India's neighbourhood? Is India losing its charm as the superpower in the Indian ocean as China eyes trade and military networks in the region? Is it wise to follow the 'wait and watch' policy or is it time for swift overt action? On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we speak to experts from the field of foreign policy to help us decode this strategic conundrum.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Decoding Budget 2018
snippet.description:
After what was the Modi government's last full budget before the 2019 national elections, we debate whether Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has tried to strike a balance between the populism and prudence. The budget announced a major health programme dubbed 'Modicare', details of which are yet to be worked out, while other announcements included schemes for farmers, women and senior citizens. What is the impact that the budget will have on the stakeholders of the Indian economy? Is this a budget poised for growth or a budget aimed for votes?
