snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is The Independence Of The Judiciary Under Threat?
snippet.description:
There are many pillars in a democracy, those pillars support each other and become the edifice and framework that holds up and supports democracy. The legislature, the executive, the media, and the judiciary. But recent events have raised serious doubts over the functioning of these pillars as independent bodies, as four top Supreme Court Judges publicly highlighted some of the issues being faced by the judiciary. Allegations include the partiality displayed in the allocation of high profile cases, that junior judges are assigned to constitution benches, and biased decisions taken by the Chief Justices in the present and the past. This begs us to ask the question - is the freedom of our state institution under threat? Are bodies such as the Election Commission, the Judiciary and the media, being manipulated to achieve political ends? For all this and more, watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.description:

snippet.title: The Big Fight: The Political Roadmap To 2019
snippet.description:
It has been a week of two major developments that may have an impact on national politics. First, the elections in Gujarat and Himachal Pradesh and second, the landmark judgement on the 2G spectrum scam. The 2G scam was one of the major factors that cost UPA the last Lok Sabha elections and now the court has acquitted all those charged with the scam. Will these developments have a far reaching impact on the politics of the country? For all this and more, watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Is There A Systematic Effort To Undermine India's State Institutions?
snippet.description:
A very serious accusation was made during the course of the Gujarat elections that there was a systematic effort being made to undermine institutions. That is by itself not necessarily entirely new - you've heard about CBI being a 'caged parrot' for decades. More recently, the same charge is being made about the Enforcement Directorate, about the Income Tax Department, about other enforcement wings of the government, that they are all acting at the behest of the government to target political rivals. What is unusual is that the Election Commission was brought into it and a specific allegation was made by the Congress party saying that the Election Commission has played a biased role in the Gujarat elections and that a serious charge. Is any of this true or fair? We debate that on this week's episode of The Big Fight.

Watch full video: https://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/is-there-a-systematic-effort-to-undermine-india-s-state-institutions-474664?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Gujarat Elections - A Battle Of Prestige?
snippet.description:
Gujarat stepped into poll mode today with the first of the two-phase elections in the state. A BJP bastion, the battle for Gujarat has now become a matter of prestige for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and incumbent Congress President Rahul Gandhi. Would the election be a sitter for the BJP since it has been in power in Gujarat since 1998? Will the Patidar factor come into play and split the vote? This high stakes battle is inextricably linked to the success of Rahul Gandhi as a leader; will he prove to be a worthy leader to rescue the Congress out of a state of stupor?

Watch full video: https://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-gujarat-elections-a-battle-of-prestige-474168?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: India's Metros - In Urban Decay?
snippet.description:
There have been a spate of articles lately on the need for a new capital. Why does India need a new capital when it has New Delhi? Because Delhi is saturated in every way possible, say its critics. Its woes include over population, pollution, lack of infrastructure, a polluted river and the list goes on. Do we have the resources to build a capital from scratch or should the capital be "moved"? This brings us to a very contentious point. When one goes through a list of cities to move to, one realizes that the urban decay that infects Delhi is a common feature in cities across India. There isn't a major city in the country that hasn't been confronted by the ills of un-planned development and a lack of basic amenities. Is it time for urban planning to take centre stage? Is it time we demand better facilities from our government? For all this and more join us for this week's episode of The Big Fight.

Watch full video: https://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-india-s-metros-in-urban-decay-473637?yt

snippet.title: Experts Talk About New Economic Parameters For New India
snippet.description:
On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we look ahead at policy parameters for the Indian economy from a theoretical point of view. We debate over the direction the economy needs to take. Should there be more taxes or less? What should be the government's priorities? Finally, how can India catch up with China? Some of these ideas have been thrown in by Dr Surjit Bhalla, whose new book - 'The New Wealth of Nations' -  compels the reader to question some of the common perceptions around the economy. Is it time to re-think some of these age old ideas, is inequality actually falling? Is it in fact education that is the real indicator of wealth? Should we start looking at sustainable models for improving on our health and education models? For all this and more, join our panel of experts comprising of Amitabh Kant, CEO, Niti Aayog, Harsh Mander, Writer and Activist, Yogendra Yadav, President, Swaraj Abhiyan and politicians Jagdish Shettigar and Rajeev Gowda along with Dr. Surjit Bhalla to discuss the policy parameters for a new India.

Watch full show: https://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/experts-talk-about-new-economic-parameters-for-new-india-473111?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: The Big Row Over Padmavati
snippet.description:
The row over celebrated Director Sanjay Leela Bhansali's latest offering Padmavati has been simmering for a while now. The first attack took place at Jaigarh Fort in Jaipur when members of the fringe political group Karni Sena stormed into the set and slapped the director. Months later, the set of the film was vandalised and set on fire in Kohlapur, Maharashtra. The row was over an alleged intimate scene between the characters of Queen Padmavati and Alauddin Khilji, that the director subsequently clarified did not exist. Fringe groups have now threatened violence against the lead actor and the director of the film if it is released on its designated date of December 1st, 2017. While tension continues to simmer, in an unrelated development, two highly acclaimed films were dropped from India's most reputed International Film Festival with no explanations offered. Keeping these two major events in mind, the question that begs to be answered is one that pertains to the freedom of expression. Can artistic licence be unbridled? Will India ever be able to produce films based on historical or political themes because it could possibly hurt the sentiments of one group or another? Experts claim that this isn't a new trend and has been going on for ages irrespective of who is in power. Does this leave any room for negotiation? How can India continue to produce award winning films if freedom of expression is constantly curtailed?

Watch full video: https://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-the-big-row-over-padmavati-472621

snippet.title: Demonetisation: One Year On
snippet.description:
It has been one year since that fateful day when Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the biggest ever demonetisation exercise as a result of which all Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 notes were declared illegal. Over the course of the next few months, the government cited numerous reasons as to why this extreme step was taken, such as black money, tax compliance, counterfeit currency, terrorism and digital thrust. One year on, we look at whether demonetisation was a big success or a big failure? What were the short term and long term disruptions caused by the ban on currency? What were the implications of the move on the largely cash based unorganised sector? More importantly, was this a political move under the garb of economic reform? As some of these questions still remain unanswered, the jury is still out, on the impact of demonetisation on the India growth story.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is India Shining Or Whining?
snippet.description:
Among the big questions that a growing economy like India often asks itself is if the country's reputation is going up or down - what is hurting that reputation and what is improving it. This week's Big Fight looks at the things that have happened in recent weeks that have enhanced India's image - the World Bank report on 'Ease of Doing Business' is one - and also others like the attack on Swiss tourists in Agra - that have harmed it. We discuss whether India is shining or do we whine too much about things around us? Do headlines spread negativity or do they help raise awareness about issues that the government must look at?

Watch full video: https://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-is-india-shining-or-whining-471545?yt

snippet.title: Best Mode Of Investment Around Diwali
snippet.description:
It is that time of the year again. The festival season is upon us and with that comes the question, is it time to splurge or save? Diwali is considered one of the most auspicious times of the year to invest, and on this Diwali special episode of The Big Fight, we discuss your investment options for the festive season. Is it time for you to ride the market or investment in the rocky real estate sector? Should you buy traditional favourites, like gold and jewellery on dhanteras, or should you make the most of the festival offers and buy that new mobile phone you've been eyeing for months? If you need expert advice on where to put your money, then watch this episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Air Pollution - A Silent Killer
snippet.description:
Air pollution is perhaps the most silent of killers we'll see in our lifetimes. The air we breathe has become toxic and it is time that we come up as a collective to raise concerns about this menace. The Supreme Court, in a recent observation, said that crackers should not be burnt this Diwali since the adverse impact that it has on the environment cannot be ignored anymore. As a consequence it put an immediate ban on the sale of crackers in the national capital region extending till the end of the month. Is this too small a step? Does the government need to do more? The air pollution in north India is also blamed on the smoke from stubble burning in Punjab and Haryana. How can the government take care of the needs of farmers and prevent them from indulging in this age-old practice? Can we give the future generation better air and a better quality of life? If the answer to that is yes, then we need to start now.

Watch full show: https://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-air-pollution-a-silent-killer-470028?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: What Ails The Economy?
snippet.description:
Niti Aayog's Bibek Debroy referred to it as a 'minor cold', while former Finance Minister Yashwant Sinha said that the 'economy was poised for a hard landing', so what kind of a slowdown is the economy facing? The GDP has witnessed a steady decline as India faces structural problems in the implementation of big bang reforms such as the GST and demonetisation. Has the government done too much, too soon? Or is this a passing phase that will only make the economy stronger? On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we look at the top five reasons behind the economic slowdown. We ask experts whether the slowdown is temporary or will it leave a deep imprint on our economic lives.  Write in to us at bigfight@ndtv.com to share your concerns about the health of the economy.

snippet.title: Big Fight with Vikram Chandra | Simultaneous Polls: Aye Or Nay?
snippet.description:
On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we debate whether holding simultaneous elections is a good idea or not. What does 'simultaneous elections' mean? Niti Aayog defines it as follows: It involves the structuring of Indian election cycle in a manner that elections to Lok Sabha and State Assemblies are synchronized together. In such a scenario, a voter would normally cast their vote for electing members of Lok Sabha and State Assembly on a single day and at the same time.
The idea is not new to India and has recently seen favour with both the Prime Minister and the President of the BJP. Will holding simultaneous elections help curb corruption, will it also reduce election expenditure and black money or is the idea too Utopian to be implemented in a democracy like India? Watch this episode as we go through all the nuances of the debate, and send us your feedback on bigfight@ndtv.com

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/should-nris-be-allowed-to-vote-through-proxies-466817?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight On Dynastic Politics
snippet.description:
On a recent visit to America, Congress Vice President, Rahul Gandhi insinuated that dynastic politics not only works in India but it is what people prefer. On this episode of The Big Fight, we debate whether there is any truth in that statement. A quick glance at the current Lok Sabha proves that Congress is by far the most dynastic of all parties with as many as 48% of its MPs from political families. BJP on the other hand, has that number limited to 15%, as both the Prime Minister and the BJP President are not from political parties. In India, the hard reality is that dynasties perpetuate in most if not all major political parties in India. What are the repercussions of this? Does dynastic politics deplete or add to the pool of talent in the legislature? And its not just politics, a majority of big ticket companies in India are also family owned. Does this prove beyond doubt that Indians prefer dynasts over those with merit? Is dynasto-cracy and meritocracy mutually exclusive?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/should-nris-be-allowed-to-vote-through-proxies-466817?yt

snippet.title: Should NRIs Be Allowed To Vote Through Proxies?
snippet.description:
Last month, the government took a decision to allow non-resident Indians or NRIs to nominate a proxy to vote in elections. The condition is that both the NRI and the proxy should be from the same constituency and the choice is only confined to elections. While the Parliament is yet to take up the matter and allow it, critics, including former Chief Election Commissioners, have expressed concern that it would violate the model code of secret ballots. If indeed proxy voting is deemed fit to be implemented, then shouldn't the same rule apply to migrants? It should be borne in mind that NRIs already have a legitimate right to vote which was bestowed to them during UPA-II. The only bone of contention was to figure out the modalities. It's true that NRIs have been the flagbearers of Indian culture for decades -- particularly in the US, Gulf countries and in Western Europe, but of late they have been playing an important role in promoting India in their country of residence backed by their growing financial clout. But will proxy voting disrupt the process of voting in India? Will an NRI, notwithstanding their love for their motherland, be able to make judicious choice of selecting the 'right' candidate based on his/her performance without being swayed by party manifestos and ideologies?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/should-nris-be-allowed-to-vote-through-proxies-466817?yt

snippet.title: The Internet: Where Threats Lurk For Children?
snippet.description:
Could you ever imagine that a name as innocuous as 'Blue Whale Challenge' is actually a secret online game that provokes vulnerable teenagers to go through a series of tasks and dares that eventually lead to them taking their own lives? Although India has seen only a handful of suspected deaths so far, cyber bullying and virtual suicide challenges are here to stay. How we create a firewall that will protect our children from these threats? Is this the responsibility of schools, parents or do we need some sort of a collective effort to create awareness about predatory apps or games?

On this episode of The Big Fight, we look at all the aspects around cyber bullying - who are the most vulnerable, what can parents do when they are totally disconnected with their children's virtual reality, and should schools conduct digital workshops to apprise young students of the imminent dangers lurking online?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-internet-where-threats-lurk-for-children-465744?yt

snippet.title: India At 70: The Highs And Lows
snippet.description:
We are about to complete 70 years of our independence. From being the poster boy of poverty and branded as a land of snake-charmers, India has come a long way. Cynics had doubted whether India would even survive even for a few years with its experiment of being a democratic country amidst a wide range of diversity - religious, linguistic, racial to name a few. Though India has pulled out millions of people from the scourge of poverty, yet several millions still go to bed hungry. The last few decades have seen religious fault lines increasing with fundamentalism rearing its ugly head. While India is now recognised as a soft power, employment generation remains a major headache. Where do we go from here? Will India be able to reclaim its glorious past?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/india-at-70-the-highs-and-lows-465193?yt

snippet.title: Raids: Anti-Corruption Or Anti-Opposition?
snippet.description:
The Income Tax raids on opposition leaders like Lalu Yadav, Congress leader from Karnataka DK Shivakumar, and the questioning and incarcerating of Trinamool lawmakers for 'alleged' involvement in Saradha chit fund case and Narada sting case in West Bengal has had opposition accusing the BJP-led NDA government at the Centre of carrying out vendetta politics. The opposition's charge is that the central investigative agencies are not showing the same alacrity when it comes  to pursuing cases against BJP leaders - Vyapam Scam against the Madhya Pradesh government, Rajasthan Chief Minister Vasundhara Raje and External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj for their alleged help to businessman Lalit Modi in evading arrest and leaving the country. The BJP, however, claims that central agencies have possession of 'substantial' documents to prove that these cases against the opposition leaders were not politically motivated. Fo investigative agencies act according to the wishes of their political masters? Has it become a norm for the government of the day to use these agencies against political opponents? The other important issue currently raging in Kerala are political murders where scores of RSS-BJP, CPM, Congress and IUML workers have been murdered as a part of vendetta politics. Is there a way to put an end to it?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: 2019 Polls - NDA In Pole Position?
snippet.description:
Nitish Kumar's 'Ghar Wapsi' has thrown the opposition into complete disarray. The dream of weaving a grand coalition is now in tatters - with the loss of a clean, competent, credible face - now back in National Democratic Alliance's fold, the BJP's job for 2019 polls appears more than half done.  But is it so? Can the BJP increase its tally beyond 282 seats that they got in 2014 general elections? In the last general election, BJP swept Gujarat, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh, Delhi, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand and reduced the opposition to a few seats in Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh. It's really difficult to increase its seats from these states. If NDA has to increase its tally it must look at those states where its performance was way below even satisfactory level - West Bengal, Odisha, Tamil Nadu, Kerala - where BJP won a paltry five seats out of 120. However, political experts believe that it is not the electoral arithmetic that works in India but rather the mood of the people, the 'wave' or the lack of it, that decides the outcome. No doubt, as of today, NDA under PM Narendra Modi is in an advantageous position and the opposition is grappling to figure out ways to counter him. But with elections more than a year-and-half away and the Indian electorate never failing to throw up a surprise, can a fight be completely written off?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-2019-polls-nda-in-pole-position-464092?yt

The dream of weaving a grand coalition is now in tatters - with the loss of a clean, competent, credible face - now back in National Democratic Alliance's fold, the BJP's job for 2019 polls appears more than half done.  But is it so? Can the BJP increase its tally beyond 282 seats that they got in 2014 general elections? In the last general election, BJP swept Gujarat, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh, Delhi, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand and reduced the opposition to a few seats in Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh. It's really difficult to increase its seats from these states. If NDA has to increase its tally it must look at those states where its performance was way below even satisfactory level - West Bengal, Odisha, Tamil Nadu, Kerala - where BJP won a paltry five seats out of 120. However, political experts believe that it is not the electoral arithmetic that works in India but rather the mood of the people, the 'wave' or the lack of it, that decides the outcome. No doubt, as of today, NDA under PM Narendra Modi is in an advantageous position and the opposition is grappling to figure out ways to counter him. But with elections more than a year-and-half away and the Indian electorate never failing to throw up a surprise, can a fight be completely written off?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-2019-polls-nda-in-pole-position-464092?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Should Privacy Be A Fundamental Right?
snippet.description:
The ongoing hearing at the Supreme Court on privacy being a fundamental right has reopened a long buried but an important cornerstone of Indian Constitution - should there be reasonable restrictions on privacy of an individual? Though the Constitution doesn't delineate whether privacy should be a fundamental right yet Supreme Court's judgement on the issue in 1954 and 1962 has made it very clear that the right to privacy cannot be absolute. In today's world when the state is perceived as actively trampling into someone's fundamental rights in the name of security and fighting terrorism, is it time for the court to define what constitutes privacy and draw the line?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-should-privacy-be-a-fundamental-right-463504?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: A New Wave Of Communalism
snippet.description:
It seems, at least in the domain of mass media, that we are living in an age of binaries. Today in India, where sane voices taking middle ground on the issues of communalism, terrorism and nationalism are being drowned in the cacophony of social media trolls, the discourse is increasingly being shaped by extreme voices. This was more evident in the recent events that rattled the nation - from the attack on Amarnath pilgrims in Kashmir to the communal riots in Basirhat, West Bengal. While the right-wing accused the "liberals", "Leftists", civil society and mainstream media of selective outrage, the "liberals" responded by blaming the right-wing brigade of stoking the communal fire, of deliberately blaming the minority community and posting fake news to justify the cause. Are we entering a new era of polarisation? Is there a justification in the charge labelled by right-wingers against civil society and liberals of selective outrage? Or are foot-soldiers of communalism taking it too far with communal elements running amok?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-a-new-wave-of-communalism-462930?yt

snippet.title: Border Standoff: Is China Pushing The Boundary?
snippet.description:
China has fought war with India, Russia, Vietnam over territorial dispute and has contested Vietnam, Japan, Philippines' claim over South and East China seas. Though officially, the Chinese government has refrained from a belligerent rhetoric over the standoff, nevertheless its media has been carrying out a relentless propaganda war and implicit threats against India and at times against Bhutan. It was Bhutan, which had asked for India assistance to 'resolve' the crisis but Chinese media has blamed India for 'oppressing' the Bhutanese kingdom and stoking a fire to create a wedge between India and Bhutan. All along it has been empowering Pakistan and supporting clandestinely its military Nuclear programme. How should India deal with China? Is China's global ambition spilling across its borders? Is it time for India to harden its stance?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/border-standoff-is-china-pushing-the-boundary-462352?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: GST - Short Term Pain For Long Term Gain?
snippet.description:
After waiting for more than decade, India has been brought under a unified tax structure - a feat remarkable in such a diverse country where states, more often than not, fight with the centre on issues of federalism. GST will ensure smooth flow of goods between states which were so far subjected to a slew of taxes often holding up trucks and containers ferrying goods causing inordinate delay. While the industry has lauded the single-most biggest tax reform this country has ever undertaken, however, for small traders, service providers who have little or no knowledge of the computer system, confusion is the buzzword. From making extra provision for filing returns to different tax slabs for same goods of different value small manufacturers, business owners are an anxious lot. Will genuine mistakes lead to harassment? What happens if there is problem with the software? Will they end up paying for what is not their fault? 

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-gst-short-term-pain-for-long-term-gain-461734?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: No Country For Seniors?
snippet.description:
We all have been hearing about the demographic dividend that India has. But what rarely comes out is that the population of senior citizens is also growing at a brisk pace - more than 36 per cent according to census data between 2001 and 2011. The ageing population tragically is being accompanied with its unfortunate elements of loneliness, abuse, neglect and a rise in number of cases of geriatrics. But this was not the case. The rise of nuclear families has cut the support system which used to sustain and form a support group for the elderly is slowly being eroded and the rising cost of healthcare and frailties are forcing them to take succor at old-age homes. Less than 30 per cent of senior citizens have a pension cover and the increase lifespan is making it even more difficult for them to be financially independent. Is going back to the ways of joint families the way out? Or should  the government ensure a slew of social security measures for seniors?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-no-country-for-seniors-461110?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: High On Growth, Low On Jobs?
snippet.description:
The world is in a state of flux - more so if you are entering the job market. With artificial intelligence, robotics, automation eating away low-skilled, vocational jobs what are millions of people who enter the job market every year going to do? The China model of mass manufacturing and export cannot be replicated anymore in today's world. Are start-ups the way out? Perhaps. But, only if you are a skilled worker. For all the semi-skilled or unskilled workers, the situation is really problematic. Will they depend on government doles for day-to-day existence? The Modi government had placed a lot of emphasis on skill development but the lack of a strong education base and low industry demand is affecting their prospect. The industry, while admitting the changing scenario, is looking for niche skills - nano technologists, experts on robotics, high-end researchers, experienced managers in assembly line production but our education sector has been unable to keep pace with the changing demand. According to an Ernst & Young and FICCI study, over 80 percent of India's engineering graduates and around 90 percent of MBAs are unemployable. It's high time that we completely overhauled our education system. But in the short run, people have to be flexible enough to re-skill themselves and look for work in SMEs or be ready to tread the path of entrepreneurship.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-high-on-growth-low-on-jobs-459792?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Holy Cow, Unholy Politics?
snippet.description:
The centre has imposed a ban on sale of cattle for slaughter under the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act. This has led to a series of protests in states of Kerala, West Bengal, Meghalaya and Nagaland where beef consumption is not deemed illegal. Can the centre impose such a ban? Does it undermine the federal structure of the country? In most states, there is already a ban on cow slaughter. So what necessitated the ban? Is it a diversionary tactic from issues like decline in jobs and a dip in GDP growth? Or is cow being used as an emotive issue for electoral purpose?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-holy-cow-unholy-politics-459075?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is The Army Getting Politicised?
snippet.description:
In the run up to the Uttar Pradesh assembly elections, posters depicting the success of India's surgical strike against Pakistan along with grabs of senior BJP leaders were used in rallies. Last year the Congress publicly questioned the basis for elevating General Bipin Rawat as the Chief of Army Staff superseding other seniors. And now, after the Army awarded Major Leetul Gogoi who used a man named Farooq Dar as a human shield, there has been a barrage of criticism from human rights group, a section of the media.

snippet.title: 3 Years Of NaMo: Hits And Misses
snippet.description:
Change was the catchphrase in the run up to 2014 polls. Narendra Modi had promised us that he will transform India, end corruption, bring in industry, generate jobs, end social strife and forge a new path with neighbours and word powers. With his emphatic victory in the polls people were buoyed with the hope of a transformation that would herald a new era and catapult India towards a path of development. 

Three years have passed since Narendra Modi was anointed as the Prime Minister of the country. While the government has certainly succeeded in bringing down inflation, tackling corruption its failure to generate enough jobs has invited criticism from all quarters. While electorally, BJP had its best performance in Jammu and Kashmir, the sharp slide in the internal security condition of the state has put several question marks over its inability to come up with a new strategy to deal with the impending crisis.

While time and again, PM Modi has reiterated his mantra of 'Sabka Saath Sabka Vikaas', the highhandedness of Gau Rakshaks and other fringe groups have undermined the government's desire to take along all sections of the society. 

The realm of foreign policy has been really tricky for this government. With a changing geo-political scenario the government has been grappling with new ways and strategies - especially when it comes to Pakistan and China. While India's relation with Bangladesh and Nepal has improved a series of flip flops with Pakistan and China's belligerence stance and disregard for India's security concerns have hemmed in the Modi government into a corner. China has blocked India's entry to NSG and vetoed UN sanctions against terrorist Masood Azhar. It seems that it will be a long winding road for India. 

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/3-years-of-namo-hits-and-misses-457747?yt

snippet.title: Instant Triple Talaq Superseding Fundamental Rights?
snippet.description:
Noted lawyer and BJP spokesperson Nalin Kohli made it amply clear that the issue of triple talaq shouldn't be viewed through the prism of politics since the BJP didn't go to the Supreme Court. The moot question, according to him, is the question of whether a person belonging to a certain religion would have lesser rights than others. Currently, the Supreme Court is looking at the crucial issue of whether instant triple talaq is fundamental to Islam.

snippet.title: Is Instant Triple Talaq Fundamental To Islam?
snippet.description:
This week the crucial hearing over instant triple talaq began in Supreme Court. A constitutional bench of the court is looking at the issues of whether instant triple talaq is fundamental to Islam? Whether it is a sacrosanct part of Islam and if instant triple talaq is an enforceable fundamental right? Muslim women, who have been at the receiving end of triple talaq, have found it to be regressive and subverting their fundamental rights under the constitution. The All India Muslim Personal Law Board and few other organisations, however, argue that instant triple talaq is an inalienable part of Islam. They fear that any ruling which would go against the principle of instant triple talaq would lay the groundwork for establishing a Uniform Civil Code in the future although women's organisation and the ruling party have quelled this doubt.

snippet.title: Can India Break The China-Pakistan Axis?
snippet.description:
Former Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee had famously commented you can choose your friends but not neighbours. For India, unfortunately placed in a complicated neighbourhood amidst a complex relationship with two of its biggest neighbours - Pakistan and China - a long-term policy to deal with the neighbours is missing. India's piecemeal approach based on managing situations rather than long-term plan to resolve issues is not helping our strategic interest. Does India have a game-plan to counter China-Pak axis? Does it have enough diplomatic leverage to prevent the construction of China-Pakistan Economic Corridor that passes through Pak-Occupied Kashmir? If surgical strikes, covert operations are not options against terror strikes carried out by Pakistan-based terrorists, is India in a position to impose economic sanctions against Pakistan?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/can-india-break-the-china-pakistan-axis-456476?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: BJP's Winning Spree - Is It The Modi Factor?
snippet.description:
Post note ban, the BJP is on a winning spree. Barring the setback in Punjab, BJP has won handsomely in UP and Uttarakhand, formed government in Goa and Manipur, became the largest party in Maharashtra's municipal and Zilla Parishad polls, dislodged Congress from being the main opposition in Odisha's municipal and panchayat polls, and trounced AAP in Delhi civic polls. What explains BJP's winning spree? Is it the Modi factor or is it due to the fact that there is no viable opposition at the national level?

The second and the most important issue is the discourse and the focus of the governance. While Prime Minister Narendra Modi speaks about development, governance, fight against corruption and black money, it's the fringe on the ground which is at times overshadowing PM Modi's development agenda. Is there a subtext to the path this government is following?

snippet.title: Babri Demolition: 24 Years And Counting
snippet.description:
Over two decades have passed since the demolition of Babri Masjid - the 'event' that forever changed the course and discourse of Indian politics. The demolition was followed by riots across the country with hundreds of people losing their lives in the communal frenzy. Recently the Supreme Court said that Lal Krishna Advani, Murli Manohar Joshi and Uma Bharti should be tried for criminal conspiracy. Mr Advani, however, has time and again denied being responsible for bringing the mosque down. He even went to the extent of describing the day, when the mosque was brought down, as the 'saddest day' of his life. Is there a conspiracy to frame the BJP veteran or is he responsible for whipping up the mob frenzy? The build-up to the Ayodhya corresponded with a rise in political fortune of the BJP. But today political analysts feel that resuscitating the Mandir-Masjid issue won't give them the political dividend which once the political parties exploited. Is it possible to arrive at an amicable solution on the dispute without hurting the sentiments of any communities?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/babri-demolition-24-years-and-counting-455296?yt

snippet.title: Courts: Judicial Overreach vs Activism?
snippet.description:
The Supreme Court's latest ruling barring liquor shops, pubs, bars within 500 meters of National Highways has brought to the fore the question of whether the Judiciary is overreaching its ambit. In March this year the Court had refused to intervene in the Ayodhya dispute case suggesting amicable solution between the two warring factions. While there are a considerable number of cases where the Judiciary's intervention has been sought and lauded there are some cases where its intervention has been questioned - most notably the day-to-day running of BCCI. Critics argue that when the Courts are clogged with thousands of cases it is a futile exercise on the part of the Judiciary to spent time administering the functions of our apex cricket body. However, activists are in favour of the Court's intervention vis-a-vis subversion of fundamental rights - like access to food, healthcare, issues farm distress. Therefore we ask are the Judicial interventions due to under reach & failure on the part of the executive? Are we seeing a more pro-active role on the part of the Judiciary?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/courts-judicial-overreach-vs-activism-454651?yt

snippet.title: Big Fight Over Finance Bill Amendments
snippet.description:
The government brought in 40 amendments to the Finance Bill 2017, some of which are contentious with opposition, constitutional experts branding them as not a 'open and shut' case to be part of a 'Money Bill'. Now Money Bills, according to the constitution, need not be passed or amended by the Rajya Sabha, where the BJP is in minority. So were the reforms in contravention to the basic spirit of the Constitution? Did the BJP brought in 'allied reforms' in the Finance Bill and not as a separate Bill to evade the Rajya Sabha? Are the poll reforms, vesting more powers on Income Tax officers, making Aadhaar mandatory for filing I-T returns and making sweeping changes to Appellate Tribunals a subversion of constitution? The government, in its defence, is falling back to previous UPA and NDA regimes where poll reforms were tagged along the Finance Bill. The other controversial justification, which the spin doctors of the government are providing is that the Upper House of the Parliament cannot block 'people's wishes' as was evident through BJP's victories in a number of elections post 2014.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/big-fight-over-finance-bill-amendments-453429?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Start-Ups - Unleashing India's Entrepreneurial Energy
snippet.description:
Of late, Indian start-ups have been grabbing headlines for all the wrong reasons - layoffs, sexual harassment, a dip in funding, closures - to name a few. So, is the start-up bubble about to burst? Is it going the 'dotcom' way or are we being too cynical towards a sector where historically the failure rate is at 90 per cent? There are issues that afflict the start-ups but with jobs drying up in traditional sectors, start-ups are the best bet to drive the job market. Even if the venture fails, people working in start-ups are regarded highly by corporate when it come to hiring. Should the government then provide extra fillip to start-ups like easy exit in case of failures?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-start-ups-unleashing-india-s-entrepreneurial-energy-452801?yt

snippet.title: BJP's Path To 2019: Development Or Polarisation?
snippet.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi has reiterated time and again that his government stands for 'Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas' (development without discriminating against anyone). But with the elevation of Hindutva icon Yogi Adityanath as the Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh, will the path of development be junked? Or should we view the leader from Gorakhpur as the new face of development? After the BJP's astounding victory in UP, ministers had harped on the development plan. But with Yogi Adityanath's elevation, opposition leaders and experts raise questions on whether the BJP, along with the development plan, will peddle on soft Hindutva? With over two years to go before the general election in 2019, all eyes are on the newly-elected Chief Minister and the path he will take.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/bjp-s-path-to-2019-development-or-polarisation-452224?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight On Patriotism: Ultra Left Vs Hyper Nationalists?
snippet.description:
Whether it's on campuses or in the social media, the public discourse is getting radically compartmentalised. The recent violence in Ramjas College followed by a bitter Twitter troll against Gurmehar Kaur, daughter of an Army soldier, for taking a stance that is against the current grain of 'hyper nationalism' has brought forth the whole debate of patriotism onto the surface. Is the discourse being dominated by either the Ultra Left or the Hyper Nationalists? Are the voices of the silent majority - who abide by Constitution but support freedom of speech with reasonable restrictions - being drowned amidst the cacophony of the two extreme groups?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/battleground-india-ultra-left-vs-hyper-nationalists-451011?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Uttar Pradesh - The Return Of Identity Politics?
snippet.description:
Change, development, jobs, efficiency, and an end to corruption, discrimination - it was these top promises as demonstrated by his popular slogan Sabka Saath Sabka Vikas, that swayed the elections in favour of Prime Minister Narendra Modi in 2014. But two-and-half-years later, a different discourse is being heard in the Hindi heartland of Uttar Pradesh - instead of jobs, Make in India, Beti Padhao, the high-decibel campaign is now focussing on competitive communalism - allocation of money for "kabarastan and shamshan" (crematoria and burial grounds), from netas insinuating that laptops have been distributed on the basis of religion to parties boasting of fielding a sizeable number of Muslim candidates. Where does it lead us? An unending vortex of caste and identity politics from which India has been unable to pull itself out? A gargantuan obstacle that puts a leash on the immense talent and energy that the youth wants to use to build a new India - where equality is the bedrock and Vikaas (development) is the only political buzzword? A roadblock that stifles nation building from taking a sublime form and attaining the glorious height that is only bestowed to a religious ceremony?

Watch full show : http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-uttar-pradesh-the-return-of-identity-politics-450373?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

But two-and-half-years later, a different discourse is being heard in the Hindi heartland of Uttar Pradesh - instead of jobs, Make in India, Beti Padhao, the high-decibel campaign is now focussing on competitive communalism - allocation of money for "kabarastan and shamshan" (crematoria and burial grounds), from netas insinuating that laptops have been distributed on the basis of religion to parties boasting of fielding a sizeable number of Muslim candidates. Where does it lead us? An unending vortex of caste and identity politics from which India has been unable to pull itself out? A gargantuan obstacle that puts a leash on the immense talent and energy that the youth wants to use to build a new India - where equality is the bedrock and Vikaas (development) is the only political buzzword? A roadblock that stifles nation building from taking a sublime form and attaining the glorious height that is only bestowed to a religious ceremony?

Watch full show : http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-uttar-pradesh-the-return-of-identity-politics-450373?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: The Big Fight: How Can We Expedite The Judicial Process?
snippet.description:
Any crime needs to be punished and that too in time. Justice delayed is justice denied. So why does this logic fail us when when it comes to our politicians? Is it because they are powerful or is it because we don't have the infrastructure or is it the will that we are lacking? While on one hand people wait with bated breath to see perpetrators brought to book, those, against whom false charges are pressed, wait to get their clear their names. How can we expedite the judicial process? Is setting up fast-track courts the answer or an increase in the number of judges will clear out the backlog of cases?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-how-can-we-expedite-the-judicial-process-449697?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Who Funds Our Netas?
snippet.description:
Demonetisation was aimed at curbing black money - a substantial portion of which is used for political funding. Following on those steps, the government has reduced the limit for cash donations to political parties from Rs 20,000 to Rs 2,000 and issued electoral bonds which hope to ensure any donation above the threshold has to be paid in cheque or through digital means. Is it enough to to clean the electoral funding? Or is more transparency required to ensure black money is not routed through political parties? Critics argue that the electoral bonds will ensure that the donors remain anonymous while ensuring more contribution from individuals, corporates and organisations who have a vested interest in the government policies. So is state funding and bringing all political parties under RTI the way forward? Has the government done enough to clean the system and make every donation to parties traceable and accountable? Do write to us at bigfight@ndtv.com on what should be the steps that the government needs to take to ensure a transparent funding of political parties.
Watch  full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-who-funds-our-netas-448946?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Decoding The Trump Phenomenon
snippet.description:
Close to two weeks in office and the US President has signed on 18 executive orders and memos already. The President who kept the world media on its toes always managed to leave a hint of what is to come on social media. It isn't a record of any sorts, since his predecessor signed 19 executive orders in the first 12 days of his presidency, but the one thing that perhaps stood out is how this very shrill the political rhetoric that is so markedly Trumpian hasn't faded in the face of the most important political office on the planet. However, there is no denying the fact that most of these 'executive decisions', be it the building of a wall along Mexico or the banning of entry of refugees, are issues he spoke about extensively during his campaign, so of course everything so far is according to 'plan'.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-decoding-the-trump-phenomenon-448220?yt
Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Budget Expectations 2017: Will PM Modi Go For A Robin Hood Budget?
snippet.description:
Two-and-half months have passed since demonetisation was announced. While a series of opinion polls have suggested considerable support for the government's bold move yet pundits have implied that the support is linked with Modi sarkaar's ability to give something 'back to people'. With the union budget to be presented on February 1, will the government go for a pro-poor, pro-farmer budget? Will it increase the outlay for social sector schemes? Will it bring in big-bang political measures such as targeted universal basic income for the poor? The larger question remains, how does the government plan to finance these schemes? Will there be a change in the tax rate? Will the government impose inheritance tax and bring back wealth tax or will it throw away fiscal consolidation into the winds? While experts agree that one direct outcome of demonetisation could be an increase in tax base however, it is too early to say that the expanding base will be able to generate the added revenue that will be needed to finance these programmes.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/budget-expectations-2017-will-modi-go-for-a-robin-hood-budget-447461?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Crucial Assembly Elections: Who Has The Edge?
snippet.description:
The upcoming assembly polls in Uttar Pradesh, Punjab, Goa, Manipur and Uttarakhand is being touted as the semi-final in the run up to 2019 General Elections. Not only this is a chance for PM Modi to banish BJP's political 'vanavas' in Uttar Pradesh but also re-establish that his magic is intact post the demonetisation fiasco. Though early opinion polls show Congress leading in Punjab, BJP in Uttarakhand and neck-and-neck fight between Samajwadi Party and BJP in Uttar Pradesh it would be unwise to write off other parties - particularly AAP in Punjab, BSP in Uttar Pradesh. The polls would also provide an opportunity for the Congress to win atleast two or three states and improve upon its previous performance in Uttar Pradesh to come up as a strong challenger and rallying force for the opposition against the BJP. The most important question: who has the edge?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/crucial-assembly-elections-who-has-the-edge-445918?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Demonetisation: Cost Vs Benefit
snippet.description:
Prime Minister's big post-demonetisation deadline of 50 days is coming to a close. Does this mean that people's ordeal with the currency ban will also come to an end? Will the government continue to have people's support and patience through its big bang reforms if they fail to achieve their original aim of retrieving black money? We ask, what lies ahead for India? How long will it take for India to become a cashless economy? What are the pitfalls? With a high bank dormancy rate of 43%, most Indians still prefer to make transactions through cash. Even if we are able to make that journey to becoming a cashless economy by 2020, does the government have the infrastructure to make online payments safe?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/demonetisation-cost-vs-benefit-443536?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Notes Ban, A Big Success Or Massive Failure?
snippet.description:
What are some of the questions that have been on everyone's mind this last week - how long will the queues last? How long will this disruption continue? But most importantly, why is it so that while thousands of citizens stand in queues, waiting to withdraw their hard earned money, our television screens flash hoards of new cash being seized from all across the country? Has black money wriggled its way back into the system? As we take stock of the situation, we revisit the six crucial questions we asked in our last episode - Will this lead to windfall gains for the government? What will happen with the banks? Will there be a budget bonanza? Will black money be blacked out? Will the generation of black black money be curtailed in the future? And finally, how long will this disruption continue? As the weeks pass and time closes in on the Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 50-day promise, we see if our experts still hold the same opinion that they did when the PM's scheme was first announced on November 8th.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-notes-ban-a-big-success-or-massive-failure-442788?yt
Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: After Notes Ban, Pink Is The New Black: Derek O'Brien
snippet.description:
The government's big demonetisation move has triggered an acute shortage of cash in the country and situation doesn't seem to be returning to normal any time soon, Trinamool Congress' National Spokesperson Derek O'Brien said. snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is There A Threat To Liberal Democracy?
snippet.description:
2016 hasn't been as sweet as the year had promised to be. It saw the 'unexpected' severance of Britain with the European Union; it saw the world's most powerful democracy elect a politically divisive Donald Trump as their 45th President. Were these events really 'unexpected'? Perhaps not. Then how did we not see it coming? Aren't journalists, the people you watch on your television screens every single night meant to 'shape' your opinions? Aren't pollsters supposed to keep their ears to the ground? How could this majority be left unheard for so long? Did the frontrunners of this liberal democracy have ideological blinkers on? Did they miss the signs as they marched forward? Or did they get too comfortable in our little bubble of enfranchisement and entitlement? Are these mere 'events' or symptoms of a larger problem? The repercussions are here for all of us to live through. It's not a crowd of a handful of bigots, ranting at the local town square as the 'politically correct' squirm in embarrassment. It's an entire population, that is responding to the isolating impact of globalisation, it's an entire population that still hasn't come to terms with the loss of their identity in this 'mixed' world, it's an entire population that is standing up for its voice to be heard by the elites, sitting in ivory towers, with their heads up in the clouds. This moment perhaps marks the dilution of an elitist discourse at the hands of a populist one? With this shrill a pitch, is democracy in peril? Does the world need to be subdued for capitalism to survive?


Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-is-there-a-threat-to-liberal-democracy-442026?yt
Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: The Big Fight: 6 Big Questions After Demonetisation
snippet.description:
It has been more than a fortnight since the ban on old 500 and 1,000 rupee notes was announced. For the common man, it meant inconvenience, for small traders it meant being unable to buy stocks, for daily labourers it translated into a nightmare, farmers were left stranded with their crops unable to pay for the fertilisers and there were those who had to run from pillar to the post to arrange money for hospitalisation. But all this inconvenience would be washed away only if the the 'big fishes' or 'fat cats' - those with black money - be caught and appropriate punishment meted out. Otherwise it will be the long queues, the hardships and the loss of business and jobs that will remain an indelible memory. To this end, we ask six crucial questions that every citizen should think about. 

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-6-big-questions-after-demonetisation-440284?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: The Big Fight: 6 Questions On Demonetisation
snippet.description:
It has been more than a fortnight since the ban on old 500 and 1,000 rupee notes was announced. For the common man, it meant inconvenience, for small traders it meant being unable to buy stocks, for daily labourers it translated into a nightmare, farmers were left stranded with their crops unable to pay for the fertilisers and there were those who had to run from pillar to the post to arrange money for hospitalisation. But all this inconvenience would be washed away only if the the 'big fishes' or 'fat cats' - those with black money - be caught and appropriate punishment meted out. Otherwise it will be the long queues, the hardships and the loss of business and jobs that will remain an indelible memory. To this end, we ask six crucial questions that every citizen should think about.

snippet.title: #CashCleanup: Note Worthy Or Not Worthy?
snippet.description:
More than a week has passed since Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced his big-bang strike on black money by banning notes of higher denominations. The aam aadmi had wholeheartedly welcomed the idea initially, but with hardships and inconvenience increasing, people are questioning if there was proper planning before the announcement of this watershed move. The informal sectors have been hit the worse - local shopkeepers, vegetable vendors, small farmers, landless labourers and those working on construction sites. With the cash crunch affecting the economy, will the government show the same alacrity in ensuring that money reaches those who live on the margins of the society? Because if the ground situation doesn't improve, the move might politically backfire for the BJP and political parties like the Aaam Aadmi Party, the Trinomool Congress, the Samajwadi Party are leaving no stone unturned in criticising the government for its frailties in executing the plan. The experts on both side of the political divide are unanimous on one thing - this grand move has to be followed by a crackdown on corruption, more tax reforms and bringing in regulation in the real estate sector. Will the government tread this uncharted waters and walk the talk? Or a year or two from now, people will remember the hardships that they faced the cash crunch that made them anxious with little or no benefit that accrued from this move? Will this go down in history as the big-bang move that will rid India of its black money or will it turn out to be a damp squib?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/cashcleanup-note-worthy-or-not-worthy-439376?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: The Big Fight: PM Modi's Swachh Abhiyaan On Black Money
snippet.description:
There is perhaps no better way to clinch a cricket match than by hitting that one big century in the middle overs. The game could still flip but the least it ensures a real shot at winning the match. And that is exactly what the Modi government has done. Having completed exactly half term at two years six months this November, Narendra Modi has sealed this milestone with a master stroke. A quintessential, Modi style attack on black money. All those stashing cash at home, that includes your local kirana wallah, the vegetable vendor, the property agent, the real estate developer, the jeweller, the small businessman, even the householder who saved up small stacks of money for the rainy day, quivered with awe and disbelief. The fishing net had been lowered just enough to catch the small fish. There was panic and anxiety too, as the coming days saw shop owners refuse old 500, 1000 rupee notes, COD or cash on delivery declined as cashless payment companies sprung into actions with payment codes appearing in even tea-stalls. The shrewd Indian brain sprang into action, coming up with innovative ways or jugaad to convert black into white. But what does this really mean for the economy at large? How much cash will the government be able to accumulate through this new move? Can this move be linked to the upcoming elections in UP and Punjab? Does this small step to stir up the domestic market mean that the government is willing to go after the black money stacked away in banks across the world?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-pm-modi-s-swachh-abhiyaan-on-black-money-438443?yt
Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: '1,000 Shades Of Grey': A Tale Of 'Capital' Pollution
snippet.description:
Like Diwali, air pollution has also become a part of north India's ritual, one that no one looks forward to but is a byproduct of everything that is wrong with urban India - mis-governance, political apathy, lack of concern for the environment, poor implementation of green laws, improper planning etc. Policymakers were well aware of the impending crisis of air pollution, but little or nothing was done to prevent it. Small yet meaningful measures such as vacuuming of roads, sprinkling of water was not done. The situation worsened further by smoke rising from crop burning in neighbouring states such as Punjab and Haryana, and cracker bursting during the festival of Diwali. Now, most of northern India sits with a cloud of deadly smog hovering over it, the air quality index hit 'severe' for several cities in the region. Experts on the show, Chandra Bhushan from Centre for Science and Environment and Dr. Guleria, a renowned Pulmonologist claimed that this air pollution could lead to thousands of deaths as the air puts at risk children as well as adults. If this is not a wake up call then what is?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/1000-shades-of-grey-a-tale-of-capital-pollution-437592?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Big Fight Diwali Special: What Is The Best Mode Of Investment?
snippet.description:
With interest rates on safe and secure small savings schemes lowering year after year, when it is not even possible to match inflationary figures anymore, where does one invest? Real Estate? Does the quest for a 'home' stand a chance as the only sector where prices stand corrected? Or should one invest 'systematically' in mutual funds which for the past few years has consistently given returns higher than the average inflationary figure? What about investing in the stock market? Can those who have limited knowledge about stocks bear the ups and downs the market offers? Or should people repose their faith on the time tested, age-old mode of investment and exchange, gold? Join us on The Big Fight as we bring to you professional experts, financial planners, fund managers to help you decide on the best mode of investment this Diwali

snippet.title: Should Celebrities Be Held Criminally Liable For Endorsements?
snippet.description:
Last year, a government testing laboratory found 'excess' lead in Maggi - one of the most popular brands of instant noodles. The brand ambassadors of the product, actors Amitabh Bachchan, Madhuri Dixit and Preity Zinta were not only flayed on social media but a case was filed against them in a local court in Uttar Pradesh. The case rested on the logic that celebrities should be held accountable for any product they endorse, since the celebrities, have a mass following and have the ability to sway people. The discourse on making celebrities accountable for misleading adverts was given a shot in the arm when the Parliamentary Standing Committee made recommendations on making celebrities accountable. Based on which, the government has prepared a draft Bill proposing criminal liabilities on celebrities featuring in misleading advertisements. It says that court can take 'cognisance' of a false or misleading endorsement if the complaint is being filed by an officer of the Central Consumer Protection Authority. Though the draft bill makes it clear that consumers won't be able to drag a celebrity to court yet the endorsers are up in arms as they say that it is impossible to validate the claims made by the manufacturers since only an expert is qualified to exercise such due diligence. Can celebrities be expected to self-regulate or should the power lie in the hands of the consumer?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/should-celebrities-be-held-criminally-liable-for-endorsements-436012?yt
Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Should The State Intervene In Religious Practices?
snippet.description:
Fasting has been an integral part of organized religion in India. Sometimes fasting is undertaken for the betterment of worldly life and at times for renunciation of material comfort. But the 'Lakshman Rekha' was breached when Aradhana Samdhariya - a 13-year-old girl - suffered a fatal heart attack after completing a fast that lasted 68 days. Her death shocked the country, as her funeral procession was turned into a 'shobha yatra' in an attempt by her community to extol her virtues. It was only after the Child Rights Organizations filed a complaint that a case of culpable homicide not amounting to murder was registered against the Jain teen's parents.

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/should-the-state-intervene-in-religious-practices-435143?yt

snippet.title: Uniform Civil Code, A Political Agenda?
snippet.description:
Kamal Faruqui, member of All India Muslim Personal Law Board, didn't mince his words when he said that Uniform Civil Code is a political agenda which is impossible to implement in India. Dropping a hint that consensus would even elude different religions and sects among the majority of the population, Kamal Faruqui added that the draft Code Bill first be discussed among the other sections of the population and then the Muslim community's view should be sought.

snippet.title: Post Surgical Strikes: The Changing Dynamics Of Indo-Pak Engagement
snippet.description:
Whatever one calls it - a daring move, a game-changer, a paradigm shift - the bottomline is that  Prime Minister Narendra Modi has changed the rules of engagement with Pakistan post the September 29 surgical strikes against terror launch pads across the Line of Control. India received tremendous support from its neighbours especially from SAARC countries, which has pushed Pakistan into a corner. The US, while remaining silent on the strikes, has called on Pakistan to act against terror outfits. So what will Pakistan do now - live in denial about the surgical strikes and blame India for fanning the flame in Balochistan or wait for an opportunity to carry out another terror strike in India through its proxies whom they refer as 'non-state actors'? Or has the surgical strikes forced them to think twice before making another attempt to bleed India? The future of Indo-Pak relations might take an unpredictable turn but PM Modi's message to Pakistan is clear - an attack on India will not go unpunished.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/post-surgical-strikes-the-changing-dynamics-of-indo-pak-engagement-433343?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Uri Attack Fallout: What Are India's Options?
snippet.description:
The death of 18 soldiers in Uri attack this month, is perhaps the most belligerent attack staged  by Pakistan-based terrorists during Prime Minister Narendra Modi's regime. PM Modi, who had caustically remarked on the soft posturing of the UPA government during terror attacks, now finds himself in a unenviable position where under immense pressure from public and political parties, he has to match up his rhetoric or come up with a solution that serves him to contain the surge of domestic anger against India's neighbour. Pathankot attack sounded the death knell of the peace process that Prime Minister Narendra Modi had begun early in his tenure. Now after the barbaric attack in Uri, is a military strike the only option? Or should India consider covert, targeted attacks in Pakistan? Does India have the covert capabilities to hurt Pakistan? Has the diplomatic push by the Modi government yielded any result? Will the world, especially the US, put pressure on Pakistan to take action against radical anti-India elements? Or despite being labelled as a 'soft' state time and again, India will have to fall back upon the very well-traversed road of condemning Pakistan's terror activities by opening a new channel of dialogue?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/uri-attack-fallout-what-are-india-s-options-432530?yt
Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Kejriwal wants only loyalists in party: Ex-AAP member Mayank Gandhi
snippet.description:
Former AAP member Mayank Gandhi came down heavily on the party chief Arvind Kejriwal for taking the anti-corruption movement downhill. Giving an insight into the functioning of AAP, Mr Kejriwal's former fellow party member revealed that the Delhi Chief Minister had once confided in him that he doesn't want any intelligent people in his party and he only wanted loyal people who will follow his stance.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is Aam Aadmi Party imploding?
snippet.description:
First came the purge of founder members of AAP from the party, then a series of arrests of AAP MLAs followed by CDs indicting AAP leaders of corruption, sex scandals. The party, which has always prided itself for being different - offering a transparent governance based on principles of non-corruption, high moral and ethical values - suddenly seemed like any other political party. However, the real sting in the criticism has come from none other than the anti-corruption crusader Anna Hazare who had 'high hopes' from Arvind Kejriwal. The veteran has questioned  AAP chief's style of functioning and criticised him on not paying due diligence while appointing members and ministers. In its defence. the AAP has cited a number of cases where courts have questioned the motive of Delhi police and the vindictive nature of the Modi government? The question everyone is asking is - what has happened to AAP - is it imploding?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-is-aam-aadmi-party-imploding-430805?yt

snippet.title: Urban flooding: A 'sinking' reality?
snippet.description:
You must have seen these images. People fishing in IT hub Bengaluru when it was flooded, India's Millennium City Gurgaon looking like Venice with flooded streets sans Gondolas, people stranded in Mumbai with rail services disrupted due to rains and cars floating in an inundated Hyderabad. The picture is same everywhere - urban India can't cope up with monsoon rains. Why is it that a country which aspires to be superpower lacks properly planned cities? Why is that in every city the 'natural drainage' system has been destroyed? Why is that every inch of open space, storm-water drains have been encroached upon by illegal construction? Why is it that environmental laws have been bypassed by 'Builder-Babu-Neta' nexus? Are our cities heading towards an urban chaos? Can we as citizens hope to see political will and consensus over 'fixing' our cities?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/urban-flooding-a-sinking-reality-429963?yt

snippet.title: 'Take concrete steps or be prepared to drown'
snippet.description:

snippet.title: Is PM Modi soft on Kashmir, tough on Pakistan?
snippet.description:
The Prime Minister's Independence Day speech from the ramparts of the Red Fort was remarkable for one reason - the gratitude he extended towards the people of Balochistan, Gilgit & PoK. Was it simply an off-the-cuff remark or was it a cool calculative step that India had been planning quietly for sometime as a bait against Pakistan's huffing and puffing over Kashmir on international forums? The other sore point that got mentioned in the Prime Minister's speech was the centre's placatory gesture towards Jammu and Kashmir and the subsequent efforts by both state and central government to stop the violence in the valley. So is this PM Modi's new game-plan of being tough on Pakistan and soft on Kashmir? Will a new set of interlocutors be able to provide the much needed 'healing touch' or will it remain only a cosmetic procedure?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/is-pm-modi-soft-on-kashmir-tough-on-pakistan-429078?yt

snippet.description:

snippet.title: India@Olympics: How can we ensure more medals?
snippet.description:
We are a nation of 1.2 billion people but when it comes to sports we lag behind others. Why is it so? Do we lack a sporting culture in this country? Is bureaucratic apathy the reason? How many times have we heard athletes complain about inadequate facilities? Wrestling has brought us medals in the last three Olympics, but what have we done to alleviate the pathetic condition under which they have to undergo their training. Recently we saw this heart-wrenching story of a group of teenagers practicing swimming in a dam in Jharkhand. The swimmers could be potential athletes representing us at the Asian Games or even the Olympics. Do we have a right to blame them if they fail to win a medal? The other moot point that often explains why we fail to produce a stream of great athletes like USA, China is due to lack of proper infrastructure and the lack of importance we attach to sports in our schools. How many parents enthusiastically support their kids if they want to pursue sports as a profession? Has the time come to make sports compulsory in school curriculum? We discuss: the steps should we take to ensure we get more medals in Tokyo Olympics in 2020.

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/india-olympics-how-can-we-ensure-more-medals-428162?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source %3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Have been shamed, it backfired: Shobhaa De to NDTV
snippet.description:
Writer and socialite Shobhaa De received a lot of flak online and offline over her tweet on India's initial performance in Rio Olympics. Accusing Team India of wasting time and money, Ms De commented that opportunities like the Olympics were being used as a  holiday rather than to win medals. On this week's episode of The Big Fight, the author cleared her stand, saying that she'd tweeted out of panic and was happy to be proved wrong. She further clarified that her tweet was against the officials and not the athletes.

snippet.title: A change in discourse: PM Modi's 'new deal'?
snippet.description:
This week saw the Prime Minister speak up and reach out to aggrieved  Dalits who've been recently at the receiving end of caste based violence, calling them his 'brethren'. PM Modi also reprimanded 'cow vigilante' groups referring to them as 'anti-social'. Speaking at a gathering in Madhya Pradesh, the Prime Minister finally reached out to Kashmiris, who've suffered violence and unrest over the last six weeks. Are we witnessing a change in discourse as far as the Prime Minister is concerned? Or is it an election ploy keeping in mind the upcoming polls in Uttar Pradesh and Gujarat in 2017? Should the Prime Minister have spoken earlier, would that have had a greater impact?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/a-change-in-discourse-pm-modi-s-new-deal-427344?yt

snippet.title: The political fight: Where is the conciliatory tone?
snippet.description:
The biggest news for the Modi government this year has been the passage of the GST Bill. It wouldn't have been possible had the Congress and other opposition parties refrained from supporting the government. To be fair to the BJP, the ruling party also reached out to the opposition and accepted their amendments on the bill. The question the nation is asking is why can't the government and the opposition come together and rise above partisan politics for the benefit of the nation? Why has a horrific gang-rape in Bulandshahr, Uttar Pradesh been questioned as a political conspiracy? What does the common man think when Delhi's Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal alleges that the Prime Minister is 'frustrated' and wants to 'kill him'? What happens to civility, decorum when BJP counters AAP by saying Kejriwal is 'delusional' and 'pathologically obsessive'? How degrading can our political discourse get? Can Indian politics rise above petty bickering and be truly constructional?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-political-fight-where-is-the-conciliatory-tone-426495?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube
