snippet.title: The Big Fight: Holy cow, unholy vigilantes?
snippet.description:
There has been a spate of attacks on Dalits and minorities all across India in the last several weeks. These attacks that have been perpetuated by self-styled 'gau rakshaks' or cow protection groups were inspired largely by false rumours about their victims either transporting beef or skinning cows. Cow, being a sacred animal in India, has always been revered, however does this sanctify the use of violence against people who are either associated with the commerce around beef or by those who consume it? Cow Slaughter is prohibited in several states in India, but is that a crime punishable by public flogging or even death? Would it be right to assume that these attacks are carried out by a fanatical fringe independent of political patronage? Finally, does this hint towards the reality that caste discrimination is still prevalent in modern India? There are no easy answers here and that perhaps makes the debate even more relevant. All this and more on this latest episode of The Big Fight.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-holy-cow-unholy-vigilantes-425651?yt


Watch more videos: http://www.ndtv.com/video?yt
Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: 25 years of economic liberalisation: Is India better off?
snippet.description:
A quarter of a century ago, India took a momentous turn and decided to open its economy to the world. With a looming balance of payment crisis on one hand and a teetering economy on the other, India was on the brink of an economic crisis. It was at that precise moment that Prime Minister Narasimha Rao, mustered political courage and gave a go ahead to the then Finance Minister Dr Manmohan Singh to 'open up' the economy. Twenty five years later we ask, are we better off? Has India benefitted from liberalisation? Has the pace of reforms slowed down? Why can't politicians cut across their ideological divide and arrive at a consensus on reforms? Would it be true to say that the benefits of liberalisation failed to percolate down to the have nots? On this very special episode of The Big Fight we bring to you some of the people who played a crucial role in charting India's future.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/25-years-of-economic-liberalisation-is-india-better-off-424810?yt
Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

Why can't politicians cut across their ideological divide and arrive at a consensus on reforms? Would it be true to say that the benefits of liberalisation failed to percolate down to the have nots? On this very special episode of The Big Fight we bring to you some of the people who played a crucial role in charting India's future.

snippet.title: Kashmir on the boil: No lessons learnt?
snippet.description:
The killing of Burhan Wani, a militant has thrown Kashmir again into a cycle of violence with protesters clashing with police and security forces. More than 40 civilians have lost their lives in the ensuing violence and hundreds injured - both civilians and security forces. Some of the civilians injured have lost their eyesight due to pellet injury. Could the loss of lives been avoided had the police been better equipped? Why hasn't the government done anything about upgrading the security forces, providing training for riot control? Is the failure of successive governments to bring a political solution to the Kashmir problem pushing the valley to the edge? Why is there a disconnect and alienation between the political establishment in New Delhi and Kashmiri youth? Are lack of jobs and development forcing the youth to come to streets to vent their anger? Adding to that is the growing concern of radical elements slowly spreading their tentacles. On The Big Fight we discuss: what can be done to bring peace to the region, which has just come out from the throes of a history violent militancy.

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/kashmir-on-the-boil-no-lessons-learnt-423992?yt

snippet.title: Religious radicalisation: A clear and present danger?
snippet.description:
It has been one of the bloodiest Ramzan in the history of Islam. Nothing and no one was spared, from Medina to Dhaka, infact it was Muslims who were killed in large numbers. The perpetrators, who owned up to the attacks, justified the killings in the name of religion. We ask: has terror got anything to do with religion? Or are fringe elements misinterpreting religious ideals for their own narrow gain? Closer to home, India has been able to ward off the surge in radicalisation yet there are concerns since one of the gunmen in  Dhaka attack proclaimed that we was influenced by an Indian preacher Dr Zakir Naik. Previously there have been sporadic reports of Indians joining ISIS. Can religious leaders in India do more to protect Indians from such radicalisation?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/religious-radicalisation-a-clear-and-present-danger-423103?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Do high marks ensure success in life?
snippet.description:
It's that time of the year when young students in thousands descend towards universities with their mark sheets in search of college education. With cut offs shooting through the roof, we ask whether marks do actually ensure success in life? Is our education system warped? Do parents also play a crucial role in increasing the pressure on students? Finally, can there be a 'cut off' for finding one's true calling in life? For all this and more, watch this episode of The Big Fight with Dr Annie Koshi, Principal, St. Mary's School; Prof. Dinesh Singh, Former Vice Chancellor, Delhi University; Vineet Gupta, Founder and Trustee Ashoka University; Sanil Sachar Author; Suhel Seth, Managing Partner, Counselage; Biswapati Sarkar, Executive Creative Director, The Viral Fever and Ms. Anu Aga, Chairperson, Thermax Foundation.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-do-high-marks-ensure-success-in-life-420480?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is prohibition 'prohibitive'?
snippet.description:
Prohibition of alcohol is back on the political agenda with the AIADMK government in Tamil Nadu going ahead with phase-wise prohibition by shutting 500 shops. In April, Bihar had implemented complete prohibition - an electoral promise which the winning JD(U)-RJD coalition said was vital in getting support of female voters. In India, there has been an intermittent ban on production, sale and consumption of liquor in some states but they have rarely been successful. It only drove the business underground with bootleggers making hay backed by the mafia. The pro-prohibition lobby have often argued that too much of alcohol consumption leads to an increase led in domestic violence, impoverishment, particularly for those living on the fringes. But is there any factual relation between an increase in domestic violence and alcoholism? Will the ban result in a thriving bootlegging industry? Is the government overstepping on individual platform?

Watch Full Show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-is-prohibition-prohibitive-418772?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Post Uttarakhand: Is there a realignment of political forces?
snippet.description:
BJP's loss of face and the manner in which they imposed Article 356 to dismiss a democratically elected government has backfired majorly. Regional parties along with Congress seeing BJP's political design have closed in and are trying to project a united opposition to the Narendra Modi government? So is a united opposition a threat for PM Modi? But will it be possible for so many parties with their discordant ideologies to stay together?

snippet.title: 'Too much misinformation on internet'
snippet.description:
In today's age where we source most of our information from the internet, it is increasingly becoming difficult for us to sift facts, information from propaganda and campaign material. Speaking on the Big Fight episode of 'Five things you want to change about the internet', Author and columnist Anna Vetticad sounded a note of caution saying that we should be careful while looking up anything on the internet as a lot of false information passes around as 'facts' and that 'netizens' need to be educated on 'ways of internet'.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: The bane of triple talaq
snippet.description:
More than three decades have passed since the Supreme Court asked the government to frame a Uniform Civil Code so that helpless women suffering from the scourge of divorce could recourse to law. But with successive governments lacking political will, women are still at the receiving end. Such is the case of Shayara Banu, a 35-year-old mother of two whose husband sent the 'talaq-nama' via post. She has approached the Supreme Court which has accepted the petition. So has the time come to do away with personal laws? Should India debate and agree upon a Common Civil Code? What about the lack of political will?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-the-bane-of-triple-talaq/414077?yt

snippet.title: ‘Army is not present in Jammu And Kashmir for tourism’
snippet.description:
On The Big Fight, we debate need for the Army's presence in Jammu and  Kashmir and the rising radicalisation in the state. In an impassioned speech, Major General GD Bakshi (Retd), said during his tenure they recovered 80,000 AK 47s, 3,000 machine guns, 1,500 rocket launchers among other ammunitions. The cache was large enough to raise an army corp. And it is precisely for this reason that the Army was sent there, not to browbeat but to manage a violent situation.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: A summer of polls in India
snippet.description:
As India braces for a hot summer ahead, Pondicherry, Assam, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu and Kerala are up for assembly elections. On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we take you through the election agendas in each of these states. We go live to Kolkata to find out what's mixing up in Bengal's politics. Will Chief Minister Mamata Bannerjee win a second term or will the BJP be able to make a mark in the state? In Assam, where illegal immigration is a major issue, we ask if that will play a major role in determining which party comes to power? Moving south to Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry, we see a five cornered contest as old foes, AIADMK'S Amma (mother) and DMK'S Anna (big brother) lock horns in a fight for supremacy. And as Kerala races into polls with a possible three way fight between the UDF, the LDF and the BJP?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/news/the-big-fight-a-summer-of-polls-in-india/412186?yt

snippet.title: AIADMK: Missing the 'picture' on the wall?
snippet.description:
On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we debate on the various contenders in the forthcoming assembly elections. Is AIADMK dictated by the 'cult of the leader', in this case Ms. J Jayalalithaa? The party has received severe criticism in the past for their sycophancy as even flood relief material bore pictures of the chief minister. Is the party obsessed with its leader and do not allow for a more decentralized approach to politics. The comment is not lost on AIADMK spokesperson Pandia Rajanas as he vociferously defends his party supremo by claiming that there are many leaders within the party, and that the party functioned democratically even as Ms. Jayalalithaa was 'evidently' the tallest leader not just within the party but in the entire state.


Watch more videos: http://www.ndtv.com/video?yt

snippet.title: Police vs students: Nationalists or victims?
snippet.description:
On this week's episode of The Big Fight, National Conference Spokesperson, Junaid Mattoo points towards the silence of the newly appointed Chief Minister of Jammu and Kashmir, Mehbooba Mufti on the current crisis between non-local students of NIT Srinagar and the Police. snippet.title: Pak probe team visits India: PM Modi's big gamble?
snippet.description:
Has the Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi taken a big risk in reposing faith on the Pakistani investigation team which is probing the Pathankot terror attack. What has changed in the course of three years that made PM Modi alter his stance of coming down heavily on Pakistan? Has Modi misplaced his political capital by investing his faith on Indo-Pak friendship? With China vetoing proscription of Jaish-e-Mohammed terrorist Masood Azhar will the double standard on the fight against terror be undermined? Will Pakistan continue to play the old game of hunting with the hound and running with the hare? What about the alleged Indian 'spy' Kulbhushan Yadav caught by the Pakistanis? snippet.title: Is Technology Making Or Breaking Relationships?
snippet.description:
It has been over 20 years since the first cellular call was made in India. On this week's episode of The Big Fight we discuss how this tiny device has changed our lives. Has the presence of this technological invention altered the way we look at relationships? As much as technology helps bridge distance between loved ones, it also acts like an impediment in our everyday interactions with friends and family. Does technology make us anti-social as we peer into our gadgets isolating those around us? Most of all, can we imagine a life without it? For all this and more, watch The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Women's entry banned in places of worship: Discrimination or discretion?
snippet.description:
While gender rights activists have been up in arms against the discriminatory treatment meted out to women in Sabarimala, Haji Ali Dargah and Shani Shingnapur temple, the clergy and self-proclaimed custodians have cited custom and overwhelming 'consensus' among the faithful to support the continuation of the tradition. In 21st century India, has the time come to break these barriers or are there any spiritual, religious reasons behind these customs? Do women have equal rights vis-a-vis men in terms of right to worship? Do religions discriminate among men and women or is it the patriarchal clergy who are misinterpreting texts to hold their sway over the faithful? Is this a battle between the gender rights activists and patriarchal clergymen or a simple question of traditional rituals being dragged into controversy for no apparent reason?  Do write to us on what you think at bigfight@ndtv.com.



Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/women-entry-banned-in-places-of-worship-discrimination-or-discretion/407603?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are we seeing a return of 'pro-poor' discourse?
snippet.description:
Indira Gandhi had won an overwhelming majority just by raising the slogan of 'Garibi Hathao'. Before her, India's second Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri had raised the slogan of 'Jai Jawan, Jai Kisan'. With a majority of Indians still struggling to find ways to enter the middle-class segment are 'pro-poor' slogans politically beneficial? If that's the reason then why is the Left - which claims to be the flag bearer of the poor, marginalised segment of India - is in a state of a terminal decline? Is the message lost somewhere in between or did the Left parties indulge in the same bourgeoisie tactics that they despise at least ideologically? Will Kanhaiya's speech show the veteran comrades of the Left a new 'way' of communication? Even if the Left parties fail to turn the tide is the discourse in the run up to 2019 general elections be predominantly Left?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-are-we-seeing-a-return-of-pro-poor-discourse/406635?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: Government arrested by social unrest?
snippet.description:
The Modi government had come pillion riding on the slogan of 'achhe din' - of rebooting the economy. But, it seems that twenty two months later the discourse has shifted. From putting its energy on bringing back the economy on track, the government is now firefighting a range of issues - from national discourse to agitation to redefining social and cultural icons. Has the government allowed its agenda to drift away? Is the Indian economy in dire need of animal spirit? Should the government bring the agenda of development back into the fore?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Good patriot vs bad patriot
snippet.description:
The arrest of Kanhaiya Kumar, the student leader from Jawaharlal Nehru University or JNU, has propelled the debate on nationalism in the public sphere. Who is a true nationalist? Can those who criticise the government's policies, raise slogans against the government be termed as anti-national? Can violent goons who wave the flag of the country be termed as nationalists? Has patriotism been hijacked by the fringe? Is it possible for one singular definition of nationalism to exist?  Is patriotism all about symbolic gestures? In this polarised atmosphere, India needs to engage in a debate to clear the fog that obfuscates the true meaning of nationalism and patriotism.

Watch Full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-good-patriot-vs-bad-patriot/404591

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are Indians racist?
snippet.description:
Though we profess to believe in the mantra of universal brotherhood yet there is no denying of the fact that there is a deep-seated bias or prejudice against communities different from our own. Whether it's the taunt that people from North East hear in Delhi or police hostility towards Africans nationals living in India, these incidents leave a long scar in our collective morality and begs the question whether such incidents are mere anomalies or is there indeed a deep bias in us when it comes to “foreigners”? There are of course cases where certain foreigners are given "preferential treatment" based possibly on the colour of their skin. Do we suffer from a colonial hangover? Or can the problem be traced back to the Vedic 'varna system'? Is education the best way to rid our society of such prejudices? We debate on The Big Fight.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-are-indians-racist/403650?yt

Download the NDTV news app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.july.ndtv&referrer=utm_source%3Dyoutubecards%26utm_medium%3Dcpc%26utm_campaign%3Dyoutube

snippet.title: 'Police biased against Africans'

snippet.title: Is it time to scrap Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code?
snippet.description:
An archaic British law, dating back over a hundred and fifty years is before the top court in India. The Supreme Court now needs to decide whether it is indeed time to scrap Section 377 of Indian Penal Code that criminalises homosexuality and makes gay sex illegal thereby infringing on the fundamental rights of the individual. Though attitudes towards homosexuality have undergone significant changes, it would only be fair to acknowledge that it is nonetheless a deeply divisive issue in India. Is this a matter of a majoritarian morality infringing upon the rights of the minority? Will the top court uphold its own legacy as a counter-majoritarian institution? Is the question of morality irrelevant when it comes to protecting the fundamental rights of an individual? We debate all this and more on The Big Fight.

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/is-it-time-to-scrap-section-377-of-the-indian-penal-code/402566?yt

snippet.title: Arunachal Pradesh: Stuck between Congress and BJP?
snippet.description:
The simmering political tension that was brewing in Arunachal Pradesh for the last few months reached an ugly denouement with the President dismissing the Nabam Tuki-led Congress government based on Governor Rajkhowa's report. We debate the intricacies of the Arunachal crisis, its causes and implications as the matter now rests with the Supreme Court of India. Is the Arunachal crisis really unnecessary? A peaceful state that shares a precarious border with China, Arunachal Pradesh has been claimed by China, from time to time. In this context Arunachal is crucial as it gives subversive elements a traction in a faction-ridden political environment where all stakeholders are looking to form the Government. Has the government mishandled the situation? Should the government have resisted invoking Article 356? Is centre-state relations always fraught with difficulties, if yes then who bears the brunt of such an engagement?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/arunachal-pradesh-stuck-between-congress-and-bjp/401468?yt

http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/arunachal-pradesh-stuck-between-congress-and-bjp/401468

snippet.title: Mess in Arunachal Pradesh not new, says Mohan Guruswamy
snippet.description:
On the issue of President's rule in Arunachal Pradesh, Mohan Guruswamy, an economist and expert on China, said that despite India combating claims by China over Arunachal Pradesh, successive Indian governments have failed to bring in development to the state. They have made a mess of democracy by encouraging horse-trading and defections of legislators to prop their own government, he claims.

snippet.title: Pathankot terror attack: Litmus test for PM Modi's Pakistan policy?
snippet.description:
It is a trying time for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his foreign policy vis-a-vis Pakistan. The warmth shared between the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan saw rough weather as Pakistan-based terrorists infiltrated India's airbase in Pathankot. In a detailed operation that spread across a couple of days, Indian forces having suffered casualties themselves managed to eliminate the air base and secure it. However, this put a big question mark over the future of Indo-Pak talks as India has demanded prompt action by the government in Pakistan. What does this mean for Indo-Pak relations? Should talks continue despite terror attacks? Does this undermine the Prime Minister's efforts at peace with Pakistan?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/pathankot-terror-attack-litmus-test-for-pm-modi-s-pakistan-policy/398193?yt

snippet.title: India of 2016: What would you like to change?
snippet.description:
As we enter a new year, we ask 'what are the things we'd like to change about India in 2016?'. We debated with a whole range of experts from various fields on what India needs to set right in 2016. The Parliament has to function and we need reforms to invigorate the economy. What about the instances of 'intolerance' that we witnessed through 2015; is it time for Indians to put a 'ban' on intolerance? Which way should our foreign policy focus? And finally what can we do to clean the urban mess that is our cities? For all this and more watch this new episode of The Big Fight.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/india-of-2016-what-would-you-like-to-change/397286?yt

snippet.title: National Herald case: Gandhis Get bail
snippet.description:
With the Winter session of Parliament coming to an end soon, we ask whether too much of Parliament's time was spent tackling scandals and ensuing disruptions? This week, we saw Congress president Sonia Gandhi and vice president Rahul Gandhi make a brief appearance in court to get bail in the National Herald case. It was a small victory for the Congress as one of the litigants Dr Subramanian Swamy has asserted that 2016 would see the Gandhis charged of their crime and possibly even sentenced. What does all that mean for the nation? Will the Parliament continue to be disrupted over scandals big and small? Has this hampered the process of law-making?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/national-herald-case-gandhis-get-bail/395533?yt

snippet.title: Climate change: How worried should you be?
snippet.description:
The World is standing at a crossroad where if we do not put a lid on the emission of greenhouse gases, in a few decades, we shall be heading towards an environmental disaster. With the climate change conference in Paris underway, will it be possible for various world leaders to look beyond blame game and actually hammer out an agreement that everyone will follow in letter and spirit? Should industrialised countries do more in terms of providing finance and accessibility to clean and green technology? In the long term how do we reduce our carbon footprint? Should developing countries adopt a minimum-carbon-consumption approach? If the world fails to arrive at an agreement on climate change in Paris then it might spell catastrophe for the world.  Join us for this week's episode of The Big Fight with Prakash Javadekar, Union Environment Minister, Sunita Narain, environmental activist and a whole set of experts from the climate change summit in Paris.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/climate-change-how-worried-should-you-be/393623?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: NRIs and their 'Idea of India'
snippet.description:
In every foreign trip of his, Prime Minister Narendra Modi tried hard to connect with Non Resident Indians (NRIs) who in turn have equally embraced the Prime Minister and have displayed a zeal in contributing towards India's 'development'. So should all of those who have left the shores of India for a better life have any stake on India's politics or should they be pontificating others on how to make India a better place? Do NRIs get involved in India's 'development' beyond paying a lip service? BJP has gone out of its way to establish a bond with NRIs and People of Indian Origin (PIO) but has that led to NRIs, PIOs investing back in India?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-nris-and-their-idea-of-india/392704?yt

snippet.title: What is the best mode of investment?
snippet.description:
Real estate prices are down; stocks have seen some correction and the price of gold hasn't sky rocketed. The festival and wedding season is upon us, so is this the right time for investment and if so then what is the best mode of investment? Equity, residential property, gold, debt bonds or SIP-systematic investment planning? Generally the safest bet has been government schemes such as Fixed Deposits, PPF etc., but the rate of inflation has been higher than the returns in the last few years. So is it time to look beyond secured small savings schemes? What would common people do when it comes to equity? Should they leave it on fund managers or should a rookie person stay clear off the stock market as there are too much speculations. localized.title: What is the best mode of investment?
localized.description:
Real estate prices are down; stocks have seen some correction and the price of gold hasn't sky rocketed. The festival and wedding season is upon us, so is this the right time for investment and if so then what is the best mode of investment? Equity, residential property, gold, debt bonds or SIP-systematic investment planning? Generally the safest bet has been government schemes such as Fixed Deposits, PPF etc., but the rate of inflation has been higher than the returns in the last few years. So is it time to look beyond secured small savings schemes? What would common people do when it comes to equity? Should they leave it on fund managers or should a rookie person stay clear off the stock market as there are too much speculations. Will gold provide a cushion during hard times or should one invest in real estate right now to make a killing a few years down the line? If you are planning your investment but still considering where to put your money this is one Big Fight you must watch.

snippet.title: Rape & punishment: Should rapists be castrated?
snippet.description:
As India witnesses a spate of sex crimes against children, we debate whether castration is a possible punishment to deter offenders from committing such heinous crimes. Is it the severity of punishment which deters rapists or is it the swiftness and surety of justice that instills a fear in the perpetrators? Will voluntary castration work in India or should it it be forced on repeated offenders? Does a barbaric crime be always met or dealt with a barbaric punishment? Join us for the debate on NDTV 24x7.

snippet.title: No country for women and children?
snippet.description:
India has been in the news the world over as a country that has no place for women, Delhi has been tagged as the rape capital of the country. In the last thirty days Indians were shocked to hear the horrific incidents of rape of a toddler, a four-year-old child and a five-year-old child in Delhi. The shock factor comes from the fact that even after a nationwide uproar vis-a-vis the Nirbhaya rape case nothing has changed on the ground. Is it a problem of policing? Will the situation change unless and until there is a change of mindset? Does the real danger emanate from kith & kin? How can we make our cities safer for our children?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/no-country-for-women-and-children/388160?yt

snippet.title: Defence preparedness: Time for self-reliance?
snippet.description:
This week on The Big Fight, Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar and top defence manufacturers talks about a roadmap for defence production and 'Make in India'. While manufacturers said that the decision-making process needed to be speeded up, Mr Parrikar said that there was a direction now, but also issues that need to be sorted. Will increased Foreign Direct Investment limit help in making way for more foreign players in defence sector? Is bureaucratic lacunae leading to delay in acquisitions? Can India be a global arms exporter in the future? Why is India lacking in stealth component when it comes to Defence products?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/defence-preparedness-time-for-self-reliance/387287?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are we becoming an intolerant nation?
snippet.description:
The gruesome murder of Mohammad Akhlaq in Dadri, Uttar Pradesh over rumours of storing beef has brought the question of growing intolerance in today's India to the fore. It took more than a week for the Prime Minister to speak out against the growing intolerance that afflicts us. All of this begs the question, is there an attempt to make India a singular, culturally monotheistic country? Should PM Modi have spoken sooner to send a strong message to the mischief makers? Is social media contributing to chaos? Did the luminaries of India's freedom movement ever envisage that our country will be at a crossroad where the whole idea of a pluralistic India would be under threat? We debate on The Big Fight.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-are-we-becoming-an-intolerant-nation/386389?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are Gandhiji's ideals still relevant?
snippet.description:
Albert Einstein, perhaps the greatest of human minds, had once said on Mahatma Gandhi, “Generations to come will scarce believe that such a one as this ever in flesh and blood walked upon this Earth.” Today when more than six decades have passed since the Mahatma was laid to rest, has India moved away from his ideals? Are his ideas utopian or is it just that in a strife-torn World that we live in we need the Mahatma once more to restore our faith in humanity? What about his ideas on materialism, industrialisation, economic model? Did we junk them and pursue a contrarian course that would have shaken the Mahatma? But what if we imbibe and put to practice the Mahatma's way of life? Would the World be then a better place? Join us on an exciting debate on NDTV 24x7 on the relevance of Mahatma's ideas in today's World.  

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-are-gandhiji-s-ideals-still-relevant/385438?yt

snippet.title: Aarushi Talwar murder case: Has justice been served?
snippet.description:
It has been almost two years since the curtain came down on the Aarushi Talwar murder case when the lower court convicted her parents - Dr Rajesh and Nupur Talwar - guilty of murdering the 14-year-old. But has justice been served? Is there enough evidence to establish the guilt of the parents beyond any reasonable doubt? Or are the real culprits still at large? What was the role of the media in this highly publicised trial? Did the media end up affecting not just public opinion but also the judiciary? For all this and more join us on this week's episode of The Big Fight.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/aarushi-talwar-murder-case-has-justice-been-served/383585?yt

snippet.title: Should reservation be determined by caste or religion?
snippet.description:
Just as we saw the demand for publication of caste-based data subside, a 22-year-old youth belonging to the Patel community in Gujarat burst into the scene demanding that Patels be included in the OBC (Other Backward Classes) list. Hardik Patel created a stir by gathering lakhs of Patels for the cause and by issuing a firm warning to the government of a continuous agitation if demands were not met. Vice President Hamid Ansari, highlighting the plight of Muslims also demanded affirmative action for the community but stopped short of demanding any reservation. Is reservation the only tool for the marginalised, backward communities for empowerment? Is it more of a political path of expressing the plight and might of your community to be recognised as a homogenous votebank? What about doing away with reservations at the IITs and IIMs? Finally, should reservation be determined by caste or religion? Should social and economic empowerment be the only criteria?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/should-reservation-be-determined-by-caste-or-religion/381716

snippet.title: Sheena Bora murder case: A web of lies and deceit?
snippet.description:
Sheena Bora, the daughter of high-profile media executive Indrani Mukerjea, went 'missing' in 2012 but no one bothered to find out. Three years later, through a mysterious tip off, the police discovered that Ms Bora had been murdered. While the 24x7 media is witnessing a series of conspiracy theories, the case has thrown up more questions than answers. Did Ms Mukerjea really kill Ms Bora? What was the motive behind the murder? Was Peter Mukerjea, Ms Mukerjea's husband, kept in the dark?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/sheena-bora-murder-case-a-web-of-lies-and-deceit/380845?yt

snippet.title: ISIS: Does it pose a real threat to India?
snippet.description:
On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we look at a group that shook the world with its acts of terror - the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria also known 'ISIS'. The extremely tech savvy terror group has made its plans for world domination very clear through various media channels, but how serious are these threats? Some might argue that it's a case of all show, no go. However, there are those who state that the sightings of ISIS flags in Kashmir have a different story to tell. The force which has been crowding our news feeds with videos of its gruesome executions, will be discussed by some of the finest thinkers in the field. We will also be joined by a family member of Areeb Majid, a young student who had travelled to Iraq to join the ISIS, but has since returned to India. We ask, does 'ISIS' pose a real threat to India? Does it deliberately target the young and the impressionable? What can India do to protect itself from this new threat?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/isis-does-it-pose-a-real-threat-to-india/380013?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight with Vikram Chandra: Are economic reforms dead?
snippet.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi had pledged to herald a new chapter by promising a series of reforms that would bring the economy back on track. Over a year since he took charge, economic reforms are stuck and the consumer-driven domestic economy is falling flat due to low demand. What has gone wrong? Is the Parliament logjam resulting in economic woes? How can the economy be brought back on track? All this and more on this week's episode of 'The Big Fight'.
